On 19 May 2020, more than 20 laid off road construction workers protested at the Azerinshaatservice company's camp on the Almaty-Ekaterinburg interstate highway near Saryshagan town in Karaganda region demanding their back pay for months of work. Protesters complained they weren't given advance notice regarding lay off which the company representative said was done due to lack of funds. [size=more than 20]

On 18 May 2020, about 30 auto parts shop owners protested at the Kol-Auto auto market in Aktobe city demanding the authorities relax coronavirus quarantine restrictions for their small businesses and let them back to work since other enterprises in the city are reopening. [size=about 30]

On 18 May 2020, about 15 traders protested at the Nauryz bazaar in Semey city demanding the city authorities reopen the market back to business. Protesters urged the city administration to let them go back to work because they have no income due to coronavirus emergency and they need to make payments on their loans. [size=about 15]

On 16 May 2020, about 20 residents of apartment buildings on 101st Strelkov brigade street and Abulkhair Khan avenue protested near their homes in Aktobe city against the city administration's plan to open the local road for automobile traffic which protesters complained will dramatically increase congestion in the area and will be unsafe for their children to go to the nearby school and daycare. [size=about 20]

On 16 May 2020, about 50 workers of the Kezbi oil service company protested in Zhanaozen city against persecution of the Union members, demanding pay raise and better working conditions. Protesters appealed to the country's president and government to intervene in a labour conflict between the company and workers. [size=about 50]

Around 15 May 2020 (as reported), about 40 residents of Shebir village in Mangystau district protested against poor quality of the local road demanding the district administration provide explanation on how the allocated fund for the road was spent by the project company. [size=about 40]

On 15 May 2020, 20-30 paramedics and personnel of the Aktobe regional ambulance service protested outside the ambulance station in Aktobe city demanding promised extra pay for their work during coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. Protesters complained they have received only a portion of extra pay and there is lack of protective gear supply for personnel. [size=20-30]

Around 15 May 2020, 3 officers of the Ordabasy district police department detained 2 male local residents on suspicion of involvement in a cattle theft incident and tortured suspects while in custody at the police station in the town of Temirlan in Turkistan region. Victims filed a lawsuit against police officers.

On 14 May 2020, about 200 retail shop owners protested at the Ortalyk bazaar in Nur-Sultan city against the market management's requirement to pay rent for two months in advance which protesters complained is unrealistic due to income losses and no business since March after the country government enforced coronavirus quarantine measures in Kazakhstan. [size=about 200]

On 14 May 2020, about 30 paramedics and ambulance drivers protested at the Salauatty Astana family medical clinic in Nur-Sultan city demanding their extra pay for working through coronavirus quarantine at the risk of exposure to infection. Protesters complained the clinic management announced its plan to downsize personnel in June upon learning of extra pay demands among employees. [size=about 30]

On 14 May 2020, 15-20 retail shop owners protested at the Central market in Kostanay city demanding the city authorities reopen the market back for business. Protesters complained they have suffered financial losses due to coronavirus quarantine and the Kazakh government didn't support them with stimulus pay during emergency since March. [size=15-20]

On 13 May 2020, about 20 activists protested on Ordabasy main square in Shymkent city demanding the Kazakh authorities remove coronavirus quarantine restrictions in the country and address concerns raised by the small businesses, farmers and medics. [size=about 20]

On 13 May 2020, a transgender person was attacked by two private security guards working for the Arystan security company at the gas station in Kostanay city after security guards and the victim argued for an unclear reason, which then escalated into an attack resulting in the transgender person being grabbed and dragged into a security company's vehicle.

On 13 May 2020, about 30 medical personnel of the Sterilization Center in Shymkent city protested on the premises against their director demanding his resignation, and urged the city health authorities to improve working conditions at the Center and raise wages for workers. [size=about 30]

On 13 May 2020, about 30 residents gathered by the mobile police post near Kalkaman village in Pavlodar region demanding the police patrol leave the area and then scuffled with the policement. Police unit was dispatched to the location where local villagers were making a living by collecting ash and slag waste at the nearby waste dump and transporting it outside the town to sell collected waste as a second raw material which state declared illegal. Police fired a warning shot to disperse the crowd. [size=about 30]

On 13 May 2020, about 40 retail shop owners protested at the Kurdas-7 home improvement market in Almaty city demanding management open the market back for business. It was closed due to coronavirus measures. Protesters complained their products have expiration dates and retail shops must be open since every other bazaar in the city is operating already. [size=about 40]

On 13 May 2020, about 20 paramedics and drivers of the Tselinogradsky district ambulance service protested at their work station outside Nur-Sultan city demanding full compensation for their work and risk of exposure to coronavirus during quarantine in the district. [size=about 20]

On 12 May 2020, about 6 owners of daycares protested outside the city administration headquarters in Nur-Sultan city demanding the authorities the final approval of the state contracts which were won in a bidding process in February 2020 before coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. Protesters complained that their daycares will go out of business if the city administration doesn't move in a timely fashion to disperse the state contract subsidies. [size=about 6]

On 12 May 2020, about 20 residents of Kodamanov village in Shieli district of Kyzylorda region protested against nearby police roadblock which was installed after 46 of their fellow villagers were infected with coronavirus. Protesters demanded removal of the roadblock and access granted for residents to move outside the town for work. [size=about 20]

On 12 May 2020, 30-40 residents of Uralsk city protested outside the mayor's office demanding a meeting with him to regarding coronavirus stimulus pay which they haven't received during nationwide quarantine in the country. [size=30-40]

On 12 May 2020, about 100 volunteers, who served to enforce coronavirus quarantine rules during a month-long emergency in Kazakhstan, protested outside the city administration's office in Shymkent city, demanding the authorities provide compensation and promised benefits for their service. Simultaneously, 20-30 paramedics protested outside their ambulance station in Shymkent city demanding full compensation for their work during a coronavirus emergency in the country. Protesters complained some of them have yet to receive a portion of what has been promised by the Kazakh government. [size=120-130]

On 11 May 2020, about 20 farmers protested outside the Maktaaral district administration in the town of Myrzakent against lack of irrigation water supply in the district after the local authorities shut down local Dostyk water canal following the Sardoba dam break in Uzbekistan affecting the area. Protesters demanded the local administration to open water canal back up. [size=about 20]

On 11 May 2020, about 50 residents of Karazhar village in Aqmola region protested near police roadblock on the main road demanding the removal of coronavirus roadblock and open access to the Nur-Sultan city where many protesters go to work. [size=about 50]

On 11 May 2020, about 30 residents of the local neighborhood near Jayik bazaar in Uralsk city protested against construction of the commercial development after demolition of the bazaar which protesters complained will leave residents with no outdoor space as a result. [size=about 30]

On 11 May 2020, about 20 municipal maintenance workers of whom the majority were women, protested in Aktau city against the abuse of power by the city maintenance department officials and poor working conditions. They demanded pay raise and improved conditions at work. [size=about 20]

Around 8 May 2020, 15-20 residents of Maktaaral district protested outside the district administration's office in Myrzakent town of Turkistan region demanding attention from the local authorities about their needs after evacuation from flooded villages. The protesters also complained that the victims were not alerted of flooding in advance which would have given them enough time to save their belongings before disaster. [size=15-20]

On 7 May 2020, about 26 quarantined medics protested against unsanitary conditions at the coronavirus observation facility in Taraz town of Zhambyl region demanding immediate disinfection of their rooms and additional service such as TV and WiFi. Facility management promised to fix the issues. [size=about 26]

On 7 May 2020, about 5 residents of Sarmat regency complex in Nur-Sultan city protested against construction of a new apartment building right next to their homes demanding halt to all construction activity. Protesters complained it will have negative social and environmental impact on the neighborhood. [size=about 5]

On 6 May 2020, about 30 striking paramedics and ambulance drivers protested at the regional ambulance station in Koschi town demanding equal pay for all health workes regardless of status due to equal risk of exposure to coronavirus infection. Protesters complained they don't treat patients but they are first responders which makes them vulnerable just as other medics. [size=about 30]
Government of Kazakhstan (2019-); Police Forces of Kazakhstan (2019-)

On 5 May 2020, dozens of rioters blocked the road near the village of Orgebas in Maktaaral district and confronted local official by pulling him out of his vehicle demanding assistance from the state to the victims of flooding. Rioters physically pushed the policemen away from a crowd who were attemting to intervene and prevent violence. [size=dozens]

On 5 May 2020, 20-30 women protesters from Zhenys village demonstrated at the local school in Atakent town of Maktaaral district demanding the Kazakh government provide housing to them after their village was inundated following Sardoba water dam burst in the neighboring Uzbekistan. Protesters accused the local administration of doing very little to prevent the crisis during flooding in their township. [size=20-30]

On 4 May 2020, about 20 women protesters demonstrated outside the regional administration's office in Kyzylorda city claiming that they did not receive the food assistance and stimulus pay, promised for the socially vulnerable households during coronavirus quarantine. [size=about 20]

On 3 May 2020, 20-30 residents of Orgebas village in Maktaaral district of Turkistan region protested near their flooded homes demanding the Kazakh government compensate them for damages and financial losses due to the heavy floods which originated in the neighboring Uzbekistan when Sardoba water dam burst on 1 May. [size=20-30]

On 2 May 2020, about 100 workers of the COC Realty company protested at one of the Tengiz oil field camps demanding the removal of the coronavirus measures imposed on the workers after one worker got infected. They also demanded an increase in overtime pay. [size=about 100]

On 1 May 2020, about 30 infected patients with coronavirus stormed out of the regional infectious diseases hospital in Uralsk city and protested on the premises, demanding release of those patients who have been in treatment for more than 14 days. Medics called the city police who convinced the protesters to get back to their rooms. [size=about 30]

On 30 April 2020, about 6 residents and farmers of Doskey village protested outside their village administration against shortage of grazing land for their livestock due to purchase of nearby land by private businesses. Protesters demanded the authorities resolve their concerns regarding pasture plots for the village. [size=about 6]

On 30 April 2020, about 30 residents of the local neighbourhood in the town of Taraz in Zhambyl region protested against bad roads in their area demanding the town administration fix the local infrastructure which was reportedly promised to the residents. [size=about 30]

On 29 April 2020, more than 10 quarantined medical personnel and medics of the Central Clinical Hospital of Almaty city protested against misinformation blaming them for spreading coronavirus at the hospital. They demanded the Kazakh authorities to address their concerns regarding compensation for their health conditions due to disease impact on them and their families. [size=more than 10]

On 29 April 2020, about 15 local residents of Auezov district of Almaty city protested against the construction activity during coronavirus quarantine near the Great Almaty river, demanding the company provides legal documents proving it is legal to build an apartment building at the location. [size=about 15]

On 28 April 2020, about 100 retail shop owners protested outside a market in Almaty city demanding the management to suspend rent due to coronavirus emergency and open the market for them. [size=about 100]

On 27 April 2020, more than 5 women protesters were detained by the riot police for demonstrating outside the Ministry of Interior in Nur-Sultan city. Protesters were demanding a meeting with police officials to discuss a case involving their fellow female activist's complaint. [size=more than 5]

On 26 April 2020, 5-10 tenants of an apartment building on Sain street in Almaty city protested against lockdown of their building due to possible coronavirus infection among residents. Protesters claimed that the city authorities have made a mistake because there is no registered infection in the building. [size=5-10]

On 23 April 2020, dozens of taxi drivers protested in Ust-Kamenogorsk city against the restrictions on their work during coronavirus emergency despite general official approval for taxi service to operate under quarantine. Protesters demanded the city administration lifts all restrictions. [size=dozens]

On 23 April 2020, about 15 paramedics of the regional ambulance centre protested outside their station in the town of Turkistan against quarantining their 35 colleagues due to possible infection with coronavirus in the medical facility without running water and electricity. Protesters demanded they are quarantined in the facility with better conditions. [size=about 15]

On 22 April 2020, about 30 residents of Lesnaya Polyana neighbourhood in Koschi town of Akmola region protested outside their apartment buildings against lack of electricity supply to their homes for 3 days which left them unable to cook food. Protesters demanded the local authorities fix the issue. [size=about 30]

On 21 April 2020, a group of residents in the village of Koktal in East Kazakhstan protested against lack of response from the local authorities to the problem of their cattle dying in mass numbers due to a certain disease. Protesters blamed the authorities for losses which would have been prevented if not for coronavirus quarantine and demanded compensation. [size=a group]

On 20 April 2020, a group of rioters broke windows and doors at the local medical clinic in Kaskelen town after learning that the authorities plan to use a facility for quarantined patients with coronavirus or possibly infected people. Rioters demanded the authorities take infected patients elsewhere. [size=a group]

On 20 April 2020, about 200 employees of the Zhambyl Suu water utility company in Taraz, Bayzakskiy, Zhambyl protested outside their office demanding their salaries in full and on time after the company cut their wages in half. Protesters complained they have yet to get paid for March and if not they will strike. [size=about 200]

On 19 April 2020, dozens of oil workers rioted at the Tengiz oil project's Bolahsak camp against the company's decision to temporarily house some other workers in their camp, as they thought it could cause the spread of coronavirus infection. Rioters broke windows of one of the camp buildings, where temporary guests were stationed at the time of the riot, demanding Bolashak camp remains closed for outsiders including fellow workers from other camps. No information on if anybody was harmed. [size=dozens]

On 18 April 2020, more than 5 residents of the quarantined apartment building 18 on Jangir Khan street in Uralsk city protested against lockdown of their building due to possible coronavirus infection of one of the building residents. Protesters complained they couldn't go out to buy food and the city authorities failed to notify them in advance. [size=more than 5]

On 17 April 2020, about 50 residents of Dossor village protested against the authorities' plan to use a local hospital for treatment of possibly infected, quarantined or confirmed patients with coronavirus. Protesters categorically opposed it and demanded they take patients elsewhere due to fear of infection in the village. [size=about 50]

On 17 April 2020, about 20 women protested outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's local office in Shymkent city over lack of support during coronavirus emergency demanding social assistance from the Kazakh government. [size=about 20]

On 16 April 2020, about 50 paramedics protested outside the main ambulance station in Nur-Sultan city demanding better protective gowns against coronavirus and full pay for March including a raise. [size=about 50]

On 16 April 2020, about 30 residents of Karabutak village in Aktobe region protested against the authorities' plan to use local closed medical facility for treatment of patients with coronavirus infection. Protesters argued a facility is not suited for and it may possibly spread infection in the village if it is reopened. [size=about 30]

On 16 April 2020, about 30 medical personnel of the ambulance service protested at the ambulance station in Aktau city demanding full wages including pay raise which was announced by the president of Kazakhstan to support medics during coronavirus quarantine in the country. Protesters complained they have yet to receive the promised raise. [size=about 30]

On 16 April 2020, 15-20 women protested outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's local office in Shymkent city demanding governmental support payment for socially vulnerable households which protesters said was denied to them although they especially needed it during coronavirus crisis. [size=15-20]

On 16 April 2020, about 10 workers of the Semey Bus company protested at Semey city administration's office demanding the authorities probe the company for withholding their wages for March and social taxes which left protesters unable to receive support payment from the state during coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. [size=about 10]

As reported on 14 April 2020, a video of physical confrontation between the employees of the territorial fish inspection and a group of illegal fisher rioters in Akzhayik nature reserve near Erkinkala town outside Atyrau city was posted on social media showing rioters setting inspectors' motorcycle on fire. Inspectors caught rioters in the process of illegal fishing which then set off a physical fight. [size=no report]

On 14 April 2020, about 30 medics and personnel of the Central Clinical Hospital in Almaty city protested on the premises of the hospital demanding the city authorities reinstate their old chief-doctor back who has resigned earlier after 182 hospital employees were possibly infected with coronavirus. [size=about 30]

On 14 April 2020, about 20 private retail clothing shop owners protested outside the Central Market in Kostanay city against the closure of their businesses due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan which protesters said led to income losses for their families since 1 April. [size=about 20]

On 14 April 2020, about 50 women protested outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's local office in Shymkent city demanding 50000 Tenge social assistance payment per family due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. [size=about 50]

On 13 April 2020, about 40 women protested outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's office in Kyzylorda city demanding 50000 Tenge social assistance pay for households with large families and single mothers during coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. One female protester was detained by the police intervening the protest. [size=about 40]

On 13 April 2020, about 20 workers of the Semey Bus company protested outside the company headquarters on Shirokoya street in Semey city demanding their back pay for March. They also asked the company file the state stimulus pay request with the local authorities for 500 employees that left without salaries due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. [size=about 20]

On 13 April 2020, 20-30 paramedics and ambulance workers protested at the regional ambulance station in Karaganda city demanding better working conditions and equal additional pay to every medical worker regardless of risk exposure to coronavirus infection which was introduced earlier by the Kazakh government. [size=20-30]

On 12 April 2020, about 50 workers of the Asmadin Project railroad service company protested outside the company's warehouse in Kushmurun town of Auliekol district, Kostanay region, demanding their back pay for several months. Protesters complained they have no money to pay for food. [size=about 50]

On 11 April 2020, 20-30 medics and personnel of the regional hospital in Atyrau city protested against the authorities' decision to quarantine their hospital due to possible coronavirus infections without leeting them know in advance. [size=20-30]

On 10 April 2020, about 20 residents of Kyzylorda city gathered outside the local office of the ruling Nur-Otan party as they found the food assistance and stimulus pay to socially vulnerable group insufficient, during the coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. [size=about 20]

On 10 April 2020, about 50 paramedics gathered at the ambulance station in Aktobe city demanding equal wage increase for every employee without categorizing ambulance workers according to risk exposure to coronavirus. Protesters complained they haven't received their pay raise after announcement of financial support to the medical workers in Kazakhstan. [size=about 50]

On 9 April 2020, more than 50 workers of the Asmadin Project railroad service company demonstrated on the company premises in Kushmurun town of Auliekol district, Kostanay region, demanding back pay for several months. [size=more than 50]

On 7 April 2020, 10-15 residents of Akshat village outside the city of Aktobe protested against the nearby police roadblock which was installed on 29 March 2020 due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan leaving the villagers with no access to food supply and pharmacies. Protesters complained they are low on food and demanded the local authorities relocate the roadblock so the villagers can buy food and medicines without restrictions. [size=10-15]

On 7 April 2020, 5-10 farmers protested at the Algabas-Zhoryk water canal in Inder district of Atyrau region, against the a rule that requires farmers to buy and install costly water pumps in order to irrigate their crop fields. Protesters urged the authorities to invest more funds into the irrigation infrastructure and assist them with water usage. [size=5-10]

On 7 April 2020, about 5 taxi drivers protested against coronavirus quarantine restrictions imposed on the taxi firms in Shakhtinsk city. Protesters called for the city administration to lift restrictions on the cab companies and allow them to work because they have families to support. [size=about 5]

On 3 April 2020, 40-50 residents of Kokbulak and Aktobe micro-districts in Shymkent city protested against the nearby police roadblock which left them isolated for days without access to cash ATMs and running low on food due to coronavirus emergency in the city. Protesters demanded the city authorities open access to the residents of isolated districts and relocate roadblock away from them. [size=40-50]

On 2 April 2020, about 30 protesters, of whom majority were women, gathered outside the local administration's office in the town of Shamalgan in Karasayskiy district of Almaty region demanding social aid and food assistance during coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. Protesters expressed their frustration with slow speed of aid delivery to the most needed families. [size=about 30]

On 1 April 2020, several women protesters gathered outside the regional administration's office in Kyzylorda city demanding food aid and social assistance due to coronavirus quarantine. One of the female protesters was detained by policemen after she started reading anti-government slogans. [size=several]

On 30 March 2020, about 70 women protesters demonstrated outside the city administration's office in Shymkent city demanding food assistance to the socially vulnerable households during coronavirus emergency. Protesters complained the city administration is too slow to provide relief to the families in need which was assured to arrive last week. [size=about 70]

On 30 March 2020, more than 10 women protesters gathered outside the city administration in Kyzylorda city calling for the local authorities to provide social assistance and support to the households with large families and single mothers during coronavirus emergency. [size=more than 10]

On 30 March 2020, about 9 private contractors protested at the office of the Taksomotorny Park bus service company in Semey city demanding back pay for 3 weeks of work. Protesters complained to the local authorities regarding their dispute with the company which then promised them to resolve the issue. [size=about 9]

On 30 March 2020, 20-30 women protesters gathered outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's local office in Kazaly town of Kazaly district in Kyzylorda region demanding food assistance from the government during coronavirus emergency in the country. [size=20-30]

On 30 March 2020, about 3 members of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan gathered near or outside the city of Shymkent demanding the country's president Tokayev provide 200,000 Tenge per socially vulnerable household during coronavirus emergency, put stop to land ownership rights involving foreign entities and suspend all legislative activity until the crisis is over. [size=about 3]

On 29 March 2020, several local residents protested against the sale of face masks for 200 Tenge each to the public at the Ortalyk Qyry bazaar in Al Farabi district of Shymkent city demanding sellers distribute it for free instead. Sellers were forced to retrieve after brief confrontation with protesters. [size=several]

On 29 March 2020, about 10 DPK supporters gathered near the city bridge in Semey city to protest against the Kazakh government's response during coronavirus crisis in the country. Protesters demanded the authorities provide 200,000 Tenge subsidy per household, restrict land ownership rights to foreigners and suspend legislation process until COVID-19 emergency is over. [size=about 10]

On 28 March 2020, about 20 residents of Zhana aul neighborhood in Makhambet town of Atyrau region protested against the plans for quarantine facility in the area due to coronavirus outbreak. The residents demanded the local authorities set it up elsewhere because of its close proximity to their children's playground. [size=about 20]

On 28 March 2020, 20-30 workers of the KSS oil service company protested on the premises of the Tengiz oil project in Atyrau region claiming that they were often interrogated by the Kazakh special police due to the possible corruption case the former owner of the company. Protesters appealed to the former president of Kazakhstan to intervene and warned the Kazakh authorities of more demonstrations if police don't stop its intimidation campaign against them. [size=20-30]

On 28 March 2020, more than 10 car drivers and their passengers protested against the police roadblock due to coronavirus outside the city of Shymkent demanding policemen to let them through. Some protesters drove through the roadblock despite police warnings disobeying officers. No reports of violence. [size=more than 10]

On 26 March 2020, dozens of local residents protested in Kyzylorda city claiming that the ruling Nur-Otan party's aid campaign left them out of food assistance for socially vulnerable categories of population due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]

On 26 March 2020, several women protested at the employment center on Nazarbayev avenue in Almaty city demanding city Mayor and the country's president address their concerns regarding lack of support from the state for the citizens that aren't qualified for subsidies during coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. Protesters complained they will not have funds to feed their families without financial support from the Kazakh government. [size=several]

On 26 March 2020, more than 3 women protesters gathered at the city administration's office in Nur-Sultan city demanding a meeting with the city officials regarding the state-subsidized food assistance for households with large families during coronavirus emergency. Protesters complained they haven't received any support from the Kazakh government yet. [size=more than 3]

On 25 March 2020, 5-10 women activists protested in Nur-Sultan city demanding the Kazakh authorities provide financial support to the households that are hard hit by the coronavirus quarantine in the country. Protesters called for the government to start implementing president Tokayev's directive to provide subsidies to citizens during pandemic crisis. [size=5-10]

On 24 March 2020, about 10 women activists protested in Nur-Sultan city demanding the Kazakh authorities address their concerns regarding their rent and loan payments during the shutdown in the city due to coronavirus risk. Protesters called for the government to suspend all payments for the families with many children until the crisis is over. [size=about 10]

On 24 March 2020, a group of residents protested against the local shop operating slot machines in Maktaraal district of Turkistan region demanding the police remove the machines or close the shop down. Protesters warned the police that if they don't act, then protesters will shut it down by themselves. [size=a group]

On 24 March 2020, 20-30 Kyrgyz truck drivers protested at the border post Aishabubu-Chonkapka near Grodikovo village in Zhambyl region of Kazakhstan, as they were stuck after the Kazakh authorities closed the border for trucks until April 15 due to an emergency restriction on exports of some food items as a part of measures against the coronavirus. Drivers demanded Kyrgyz and Kazakh authorities to resolve the issue of food transportation. [size=20-30]

On 21 March 2020, about 60 retail shop owners protested at the Arthur shopping plaza in Pavlodar city against shut down of their shops and plaza owner's refusal to suspend monthly rent due to coronavirus emergency in Kazakhstan. Protesters complained they couldn't access their shops to move remaining stocks out of shopping plaza in order to continue their retail business online. [size=about 60]

On 20 March 2020, about 10 Muslim worshippers protested outside the local mosque in Zhanaozen city against the month-long restriction on attending mass prayer during a period of quarantine due to coronavirus. [size=about 10]

On 20 March 2020, about 9 activists gathered near one of the local authorities offices in Almaty city calling for former president Nursultan Nazarbayev's resignation from the country's Security Council and transfer of his commercial assets to the independent wealth fund. [size=about 9]

On 19 March 2020, about 9 employees of the state registration service branch 2 in Yesil district of Nur-Sultan city protested outside their office demanding full switch to online regime of work to avoid possible exposure to coronavirus. [size=about 9]

On 19 March 2020, more than 10 women protesters demonstrated at the city administration's office in Shymkent city demanding the authorities resolve their issues regarding social subsidies for households with large families including single mothers with children. [size=more than 10]

Security measures: On 19 March 2020, the government of Kazakhstan introduced city-wide quarantine due to the coronavirus in Nur-Sultan and Almaty cities until 15 April, installing points of entry and exit, restricting of movement of people and car traffic in and out of the city, the shutdown of shops except for pharmacies and grocery shops. On 30 March, another curfew was introduced in Atyrau city. On 4 April 2020, Shymkent also went under lockdown until 15 April 2020. On 10 April 2020, Kazakh president announced the extension of a state-wide quarantine.

On 18 March 2020, 15-20 women activists gathered at the city administration's main office in Nur-Sultan city to protest against rising prices on basic food items in the grocery stores and markets because of coronavirus panic in Kazakhstan. Protesters demanded the city authorities address food security concerns for the households with large families. [size=15-20]

On 18 March 2020, several Kazakh women rioters stormed the Mayor's office in the town of Shieli of Qyzylorda region in Kazakhstan to address their concerns regarding rising prices on food in the local shops due to coronavirus panic. [size=several]

On 16 March 2020, 20-30 residents of Yrgaity street in Turksib area of Almaty city protested against the district administration's negligence reportedly closing a road in the neighborhood, leaving them without access to other parts of the district. Protesters demanded the city Mayor's office intervene and investigate local officials for allowing private interest to block the vital road at the expense of the neighborhood. [size=20-30]

On 15 March 2020, about 100 victims of a ponzi scheme protested on the main square in Aktobe city demanding the Kazakh authorities provide answers regarding their lifesavings which they hoped to get back with the government's assistance and address their questions on why fraudulent financial activity went on without check from the beginning. Protesters called for the regional governor to come out and meet them. [size=about 100]

On 14 March 2020, about 20 activists of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan protested outside the city administration in Zhanaozen city in support of their 4 fellow activists who were charged with criminal offences previously. Protesters demanded the authorities drop all charges and stop persecution of opposition activists. [size=about 20]

On 14 March 2020, 5-10 parents and relatives of college students gathered to protest outside the Saryagash district police department in the town of Saryagash demanding investigation of police abuse incident involving their sons who were picked up by local cops days earlier and beaten while in detention. Protesters insisted the policemen have attempted to extract forced confessions from their sons and pin a cattle stealing case on them. [size=5-10]

On 13 March 2020, 60-70 victims of a ponzi scheme protested outside the city administration's office in Shymkent city demanding Mayor come out to meet and hear them about their concerns after losing their lifesavings to Garant-24 financial service company which is under criminal investigation for fraudulent activity. Protesters urged the Kazakh authorities to protect their rights. [size=60-70]

On 13 March 2020, about 100 villagers and farmers of Turar Ryskulov district in Zhambyl region protested outside the district administration's office in the town of Kulan demanding shut down of the local quartz factory due to negative environmental impact on their livestock. Protesters warned the company of possible attacks on its trucks if the company trucks cross through their villages. [size=about 100]

On 13 March 2020, more than 10 activists protested outside the police department headquarters in Almaty city in support of their fellow activist and blogger Azamat Baikenov who was detained earlier in the day. Protesters demanded police to provide information on his whereabouts. [size=more than 10]

On 13 March 2020, about 15 activists gathered outside the Mayor's administration in Almaty city to protest and demand the city authorities implement immediate measures to protect the public from coronavirus pandemic in the city. Protesters urged the Mayor's administration to start disinfection of public transportation vehicles in the city and control supply of face masks to the public. [size=about 15]

On 12 March 2020, about 60 residents of Almaly village in Almaty region gathered at the local mosque to protest against the mayor of township demanding his resignation. Protesters complained they don't have access to drinking water and mayor ignored other issues such as bad roads and unsafe conditions in the local school building. [size=about 60]

On 12 March 2020, 20-30 train maintenance depot workers protested against low wages on the depot premises in Aktobe city. Protesters demanded pay raise and stated that they will go on strike if their demands aren't met. [size=20-30]

On 12 March 2020, several activists protested outside the city police department headquarters in Almaty city against the police-initiated freeze of their bank accounts. Protesters demanded explanation from the police officials and insisted it was due to their opposition to the government. [size=several]

On 11 March 2020, about 5 anti-government activists protested at the Ministry of Interior of Kazakhstan in Nur-Sultan city after front gate policemen refused to let them in to seek a meeting with the minister. Protesters complained policemen were threatening them with detention and they ignored activists' complaints about police misconduct. [size=about 5]

On 11 March 2020, 5-10 female activists protested outside the administrative court on Markov street in Almaty city in support of their 2 fellow women activists who were in court for organizing unsactioned women's demonstration on 8 March in Almaty city. [size=5-10]

On 11 March 2020, the police detained 2 activists out of several for protesting against former president Nazarbayev on Isatay and Makhambet square in Atyrau city. Protesters were calling for the Kazakh people to defend their freedom against the authorities. [size=several]

On 11 March 2020, dozens of residents of the Akzhayik village in Terektinsky district of West Kazakhstan region protested at the local administration's office against the quarantine facility in their village which is planned to quarantine people arriving from the foreign countries with confirmed coronavirus cases. Local youth prior to protest warned the authorities that they will burn down the facility to prevent it from happening. [size=dozens]
KazFem: Feminist Initiative Group of Kazakhstan; Women (Kazakhstan)

On 8 March 2020, at least women protesters marched through Arbat neighborhood in Almaty city demanding criminal penalties for domestic violence and adoption of the law on sexual harassment in Kazakhstan. [size=at least 50]

On 6 March 2020, about 13 activists gathered at the city prosecutor's office in Almaty city to protest against illegal demolition of their fellow protester's summer house in the suburbs. Protesters demanded the city prosecutor's office to be more transparent about the reason of the demolition. [size=about 13]

On 6 March 2020, about 20 librarians protested at the local education department's office in Shymkent city demanding pay raise, longer vacation leave and the delivery of books to their schools. Protesters complained the Kazakh government abandoned them while teachers enjoy more benefits including better pay. [size=about 20]

On 6 March 2020, more than 10 victims of the ponzi scheme Garant 24 gathered at the Victory park in Semey city to protest against the Kazakh government's handling of the financial fraud case and demanding the scheme masterminds taken to justice. Protesters appealed to the former and incumbent presidents for assistance with getting their life savings back. [size=more than 10]

On 5 March 2020, dozens of Kazakh activists gathered at the country's ruling Nur-Otan party's main office in Almaty city claiming that party was corrupt and calling for the resignation of the Nur-Otan party chairman and the former president Nursultan Nazarbayev. [size=dozens]

On 3 March 2020, about 10 Kazakh activists protested outside the police detention facility in Shymkent city demanding release of their fellow activist from detention and all political prisoners from the country's penitentiary. [size=about 10]

On 3 March 2020, 3 Kazakh activists protested at the Abai square in Uralsk city against persecution of activists and demanding the release of all political prisoners from the country's prisons. [size=3]

On 2 March 2020, about 150 sanitary truck drivers parked their trucks outside the Jangir Khan shopping mall in the town of Zachagansk in protest of excessive police fines for muddy tires on their vehicles. [size=about 150]

On 2 March 2020, more than 10 Kazakh protesters gathered outside the police detention facility in Kaskelen city demanding the release of their fellow actvists and protesting the persecution of opponent activists in Kazakhstan. [size=more than 10]

On 1 March 2020, 20-30 activists protested outside the city police department headquarters in Almaty city demanding the release of their fellow activists from Oyan Kazakhstan youth group and other activist groups who were arrested in the morning. Police released detained activists in the early evening hours. [size=20-30]

On 1 March 2020, dozens of activists were detained by the riot police for demonstrating and chanting anti-government slogans on the Tsentralnaya square in Aktobe city. Protests were called for after a video of deceased activist Dulat Agadil's body earlier in a week was posted on the internet which has triggered public discontent among the country's opposition. [size=dozens]
On 1 March 2020, about 15 anti-government protesters were detained by the riot police outside the Auezov university in Shymkent city. [size=about 15]
On 1 March 2020, more than 20 activists including one journalist were detained for an attempt to protest against the government at the Independence monument in Almaty city. [size=more than 20]

On 1 March 2020, several activists and rights defenders were detained by the police outside the regional administration's office in Atyrau city. Police blocked access to main square in the city after nationwide calls from the opposition groups and movements for public anti-government demonstrations in Kazakhstan on Sunday. [size=several]

On 1 March 2020, about 50 car owners gathered near Tsentralnaya square in Aktobe city to protest against the mandatory registration of personal vehicles that were purchased in the member states of the Eurasian Economic Union demanding Kazakh authorities to resolve their concerns over costly customs fees and additional charges which car owners must pay to be able to operate their automobiles legally in Kazakhstan. [size=about 50]

On 1 March 2020, about 20 DPK activists protested outside the city police department in Zhanaozen against the detention of their fellow activists and persecution of DPK members by the authorities. Protesters urged the people of Kazakhstan to unite and support youth initiatives in the country. [size=about 20]

On 1 March 2020, about 20 activists were detained for protesting against the goverment by the riot police at the Abai Kunanbayev monument near city hall in Nur-Sultan city. Protesters chanted slogans for the recently deceased activist Dulat Agadil. [size=about 20]

On 29 February 2020, 20-30 city residents protested at the Mahatma Gandi park in Almaty city against the new housing developments in the city. Protesters demanded a moratorium on new housing buildings within city limits due to deteriorating environmental pollution and possible risks associated with in the earthquake prone zone. [size=20-30]

On 27 February 2020, about 1000 activists including opposition figures gathered at the funeral of Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil in Talapker village outside the city of Nur-Sultan to pay respect to deceased and express their protest over his death in police custody. Protesters chanted Wake up Kazakh! and urged the Kazakh people not to stay silent anymore after Agadil's death. [size=about 1000]

On 27 February 2020, about 50 protesters demonstrated outside the City Prosecutor's Office in Almaty city demanding officials come out and answer their questions regarding Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil's death in police custody; and release 18 fellow activists from detention facility on Lobachevsky street. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=about 50]

On 27 February 2020, about 20 activists were detained by the riot police near Astana concert hall in Nur-Sultan city for an attempt to protest demanding a public commission probe into death of Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil while in detention. Activists have attended Agadil's funeral earlier which was held in the city suburbs. [size=about 20]

On 27 February 2020, 20-30 activists protested outside the Nurdaulet mosque in Aktobe city holding the Kazakh government responsible for their fellow activist Dulat Agadil's death in police custody. Protesters chanted Dulat! and said the authorities will face justice for his demise. [size=20-30]

On 27 February 2020, about 30 protesters gathered on Abai square in Uralsk city to pray for deceased fellow activist Dulat Agadil whose body was buried the same day in Akmola region and protest against the government which protesters held responsible for Agadil's death. Protesters chanted We will not be broken! and Dulat Agadil's blood is on the hands of the authorities!. [size=about 30]

On 27 February 2020, about 15 activists gathered near the monument to to Issatay Taimanov and Mukhambet Utemisov in Atyrau city to bid farewell to deceased Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil, demand political reforms in Kazakhstan and release all political prisoners. [size=about 15]

On 27 February 2020, about 30 activists gathered in Shymkent city to pray for deceased fellow activist Dulat Agadil and protest against the Kazakh government's action which they believed has resulted in his death while in police custody on 25 February. Protesters reminded the authorities of their responsibilities for their actions. [size=about 30]

On 26 February 2020, about 5 protesters gathered at the Miner's Palace in Karaganda city to express their solidarity with fellow activists' demands for transparent investigation of Dulat Agadil's death while in police detention and blamed the Ministry of Interior and the country's leadership for Agadil's demise. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=about 5]

On 26 February 2020, 20-30 protesters demonstrated outside the City Prosecutor's Office in Almaty city demanding transparent investigation of Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil's death in police detention on 25 February and release of all detained activists from police custody. Protesters called for creation of the state commission with activists included in it to probe Agadil's demise. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=20-30]

On 26 February 2020, 3-4 protesters including chief-editor of Uralsk Week newspaper demonstrated outside the West Kazakhstan regional police department headquarters in Uralsk city following death of Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil while in police custody on 25 February. Uralsk Week chief-editor beleived it was a murder and he said that Agadil was murdered because he was thinking differently than the Kazakh government does. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=3-4]

On 25 February 2020, about 50 protesters demonstrated outside the Ministry of Interior in Nur-Sultan city, following death of the Kazakh civil activist Dulat Agadil in police custody earlier in the day, demanding answers from the Kazakh police officials regarding circumstances of Agadil's death in detention. Protesters then blocked the nearby road which triggered police response leading to arrests of dozens for blocking a traffic. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=about dozens]

On 25 February 2020, 10-15 protesters demonstrated in Aktobe city demanding transparent investigation of Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil's death while in detention in Nur-Sultan city and urged the international organizations to get involved in the monitoring of the case. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=10-15]

On 25 February 2020, more than 10 protesters demonstrated outside the city administration's office in Shymkent city following death of their fellow activist Dulat Agadil while in detention in Nur-Sultan city. Protesters have expressed their anger with official narrative that deceased Agadil has consumed alcohol prior to his demise and accused the country's security service of having a link to his death. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=more than 10]

On 25 February 2020, about 50 protesters gathered outside the city police department headquarters in Almaty city following death of their fellow activist Dulat Agadil in police custody in the country's capital. Protesters demanded release of all political prisoners including those detained during the protests and resignation of all Security Council officials including its chairmain former president Nursultan Nazarbayev. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=about 50]

On 25 February 2020, about 8 activists gathered at the monument to Issatay Taimanov and Mukhambet Utemisov in Atyrau city to express their condolences to the family of deceased Kazakh activist Dulat Agadil and protest against the government's policy toward protesting citizens. Activists demanded immediate investigation into activist's death in police custody, release of all political prisoners and resignation of the country's government including chairman of the Security Council former president Nazarbayev. Dulat Agadil's death was reported to be due to cardiovascular problems by forensic medics. [size=about 8]

On 24 February 2020, about 60 car owners protested in Aqtobe region against mandatory registration of foreign-bought automobiles calling for the speaker of the Kazakh parliament to help protesters with their concerns regarding coslty customs fees and utilization charges which are mandatory to pay for car registration in Kazakhstan. [size=about 60]

On 24 February 2020, about 6 activists gathered outside the police detention facility in Shymkent city in protest of detention of their fellow activists, who were arrested during a demonstration on 22 February. Activists insisted that the rights of their fellow activists were violated by the Kazakh government. [size=about 6]

On 24 February 2020, 30-40 car owners protested across from the city administration's office in Uralsk city against the mandatory registration of their cars that they have bought in the member states of the Eurasian Economic Union. Protesters complained that the parliament and government agencies are ignoring their concerns regarding costly customs fees and utilization charges, and appealed to the former and incumbent presidents for help to resolve their issues. [size=30-40]

On 24 February 2020, more than 20 city residents gathered outside the regional administration's office in Aktobe city in protest of the local government's response to the ponzi scheme which they were victimized by after investing their life savings into it. Protesters wondered why ponzi scheme organizers are still advertising on the local radio. Police informed the victims that a criminal investigation has been launched into the fraudulent financial activity. [size=more than 20]

On 24 February 2020, 30-40 car owners, who bought their automobiles in the member states of the Eurasian Economic Union, gathered on Respublika square in Almaty city to protest against the mandatory registration of their vehicles, costly customs fees and utilization charges. Protesters appealed to the speaker of the Kazakh parliament urging him to protect their rights and grant amnesty in order to be able to register their cars without paying hefty fees. [size=30-40]

On 24 February 2020, about 7 car owners gathered outside the regional administration's office in Ust-Kamenogorsk city in protest of the mandatory registration of their automobiles that they have purchased in the member states of the Eurasian Economic Union. Protesters appealed to the former and incumbent presidents of Kazakhstan for help with resolving the issue for 170000 car owners like them in the country and letting them register their cars without paying costly customs fees and utilization charges. [size=about 7]

On 24 February 2020, 15-20 car owners protested near the New Bridge in Semey city against mandatory registration of their automobiles, that were purchased in the member states of the Eurasian Economic Union, accusing Kazakh officials of neglecting their duries to properly inform citizens about the laws regarding foreign-bought vehicles in Kazakhstan. Protesters demanded their cars registered without costly fees and additional charges. [size=15-20]

On 22 February 2020, about 10 protesters and supporters of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan were detained by the riot police at a protest rally near Aliya Moldagulova monument near Astana square in Almaty city. Protesters demanded release of the DPK leader Zhanbolat Mamay who was detained on 21 February and placed under 3 day detention. [size=about 10]

On 22 February 2020, about 18 protesters and supporters of the banned Democratict Choice of Kazakhstan party were detained by the police at the anti-government demonstration on Respublika avenue in Nur-Sultan city. Internet censorship was reported by the media near the location of the protest. [size=about 18]

On 22 February 2020, about 10 supporters of the banned Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan have been detained by the Kazakh riot police for demonstrating against the government outside the shopping mall City Center on Evraziya avenue in Uralsk city business district. 20 more DVK supporters were detained in various parts of the city. [size=about 30]

On 22 February, about 20 protesters were arrested at the anti-government rally by the police near the Independence park in Shymkent city. Internet service disruption was reported near the scene of the protest. [size=about 20]
On 22 February 2020, about 10 protesters were arrested by the police for demonstrating against the government near the Ortalyk bazaar in Aktobe city. [size=about 10]

On 22 February 2020, about 70 more supporters of DPK from across Kazakhstan who arrived in Almaty earlier to join the planned demonstration on 22 February, were also stopped on their way to the DPK protest detained by the city police.

On 21 February 2020, about 20 supporters of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan leader Zhanbolat Mamay protested outside the Karasay district police department in Kaskelen town demanding release of the DPK leader who was detained earlier the same day. Protesters chanted Freedom to Mamay and warned the authorities with mass hunger strike if DPK leader remains in detention. [size=about 20]

On 21 February, the leader of Democratic Party of Kazakhstan Zhanbolat Mamai was detained after attending a court hearing in Kaskelen city courthouse near in Karasayskiy district of Almaty, prior to the major rallies to be held by the party on the next day all around Kazakshtan. His arrest later sparked a protest in the same city and was widely criticized by the protesters during DPK rallies that took place the following day.

On 20 February 2020, about 30 oil workers protested at the Kenkiyak oilfield in Temir district of Aqtobe region demanding pay raise by more than 30% from the Chinese CNPC oil company that is jointly developing the oil project with the Kazakh counterparts. Protesting workers warned the company that they will be striking if their demands aren't met. [size=about 30]

On 20 February 2020, dozens of local residents protested outside the medical clinic in the village of Akzhar of Tarbagatay district in East Kazakhstan region against rumors about bringing patients with coronavirus to the local medical facility and possible treatment. Protesters demanded complete shut down of the border with China to prevent spread of infection in the area. [size=dozens]

On 20 February 2020, 50-100 residents of Zaysan district gathered to protest outside the district administration's office in Zaysan town, demanding head of the administration come out and clarify the situation after rumors in the Kazakh social media of coronavirus infected patients being transferred to Zaysan for treatment. Protesters called for closure of the border with China. Another protest with the same motive took place outside the Chinese construction company's project in Zaysan town, demanding 14 Chinese workers deported back to China from Kazakhstan where about 20 protesters demanded 14 Chinese workers deported back to China from Kazakhstan due to coronavirus danger. [size=50-100]

On 19 February 2020, about 20 mortgage owners protested outside the National Bank of Kazakhstan headquarters in Almaty city demanding the national bank include them in the state sponsored refinancing program to pay off their remaining mortgage payments that they have difficulties with due to high interest rates. [size=about 20]

On 19 February 2020, about 10 relatives of 4 policemen, who were previously prosecuted and charged for torture, protested outside the regional court and then at the regional administration's office in Aktobe city claiming that the policemen were unable to properly defend themselves in the court. [size=about 10]

On 19 February 2020, several activists gathered at the ruling Nur-Otan party's office in Nur-Sultan city demanding a meeting with the Minister of Interior who was there and to protest against the detention of their fellow activists who were arrested on 17 February during a protest outside the Akorda presidential administration. [size=several]

On 19 February 2020, 20-30 residents of Saryterek and Akbulak villages protested at the Zaysan district administration's office in Zaysan town, demanding the complete shutdown of the border with China to prevent a possibility of coronavirus outbreak in the district on the eastern border of China in the East Kazakhstan region. [size=20-30]

On 18 February 2020, about 20 residents of Zhanaozen city gathered at the city administration's office to protest against intimidation of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan (DPK) activists by the local authorities. [size=about 20]

On 17 February 2020, 10-15 retailers protested at the city administration's office in Taldykorgan city demanding a meeting with the Mayor to address their concerns regarding temporary relocation of their shops due to planned construction at the local market where they do business. [size=10-15]

On 17 February 2020, about 60 protesters who have had difficulties with their mortgages including women seeking social assistance from the state gathered outside the Akorda presidential administration in Nur-Sultan city demanding a meeting with the former president Nursultan Nazarbayev, his daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva who is a speaker of the country's parliament and chief of the presidential administration. Protesters complained they couldn't find justice in the Kazakh courts related to their disputes and they would like to discuss their concerns with the Kazakh officials. [size=about 60]

On 17 February 2020, a founder of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan (DPK) Zhanbolat Mamay wrote on his facebook page that DPK activist's car was set on fire in the city of Zhanaozen at about 1 am after midnight. Mamay believes the Kazakh authorities are behind the incident because an activist was under police surveillance days prior to an incident and also suggested the Kazakh government is intimidating DPK members to prevent them from participating in the DPK convention in Almaty city on 22 February 2020.

On 14 February 2020, 20-30 car owners from across the country gathered at the city police department in Nur-Sultan city to protest against the temporary registration of their automobiles that they bought in Armenia and Kyrgyzstan, costly customs fees and utilization charges. Protesters demanded the Kazakh authorities register their cars without costly fees. [size=20-30]

On 14 February 2020, about 10 car owners, who purchased automobiles in Armenia, gathered outside the city administration in Shymkent city to protest against the mandatory registration of their cars and costly fees . Protesters demanded the authorities resolve their concerns. [size=about 10]

On 14 February 2020, about 25 supporters of the imprisoned Kazakh woman Saltana Kusmankyzy, who previously worked for a Chinese company, gathered at the city court in Almaty city demanding her release from prison and dropping all charges against her which her lawyer and supporters insist were fabricated by the Chinese company. [size=about 25]

On 12 February 2020, a group of rioters assaulted a picketing Kazakh activist at the Almaty-1 train station in an attempt to rip his political poster apart. Activist said it was a provocation to intimidate him because nearby policemen saw an assault on him but did nothing to stop it. [size=unknown]

On 12 February 2020, 10-15 supporters of imprisoned Kazakh activist demanded an early release of an activist on his appeal in the Almaty district court 2 in Nur-Sultan city. Protesters shouted Freedom after hearing at the court. [size=10-15]

On 11 February 2020, more than 10 protesters gathered at the Supreme Court of Kazakhstan demanding the revision of the court verdicts concerning their relatives. The protesters demanded the establishment of a special commission for the issue, as promised by the ruling party befroe the elections. [size=more than 10]

On 10 February 2020, 20-30 students and parents demonstrated outside the Al-Farabi University on Al-Farabi avenue in Almaty city against the suspension of 10 philology faculty students over alleged misbehaviour. Protesters urged the faculty management to reconsider their decision. [size=20-30]

On 10 February 2020, 15-20 victims of a ponzy scheme protested outside the closed Gold financial service firm's office in Aktobe city demanding explanation and release of the arrested founders of the scheme from the police forces, so that they can get their refunds from the founders. [size=15-20]

On 10 February 2020, about 20 residents of the Ust-Kamenogorsk city blocked the local road traffic on Satpayev street in protest of the closure of the road crossing point by the authorities. [size=about 20]

On 8 February 2020, 15-20 protesters demonstrated in Zhanaozen city with demands for release of all Kazakh rioters who were arrested for taking part in the ethnic clashes between Kazakhs and Dungan minority on 7 February in Korday district of southern Kazakhstan. [size=15-20]

On 8 February 2020, 15-20 activists gathered outside the Shu district court in the town of Shu in Zhambyl region in support of their fellow activist who was detained for 10 days. No further information. [size=15-20]

On 8 February 2020, 10-15 former and current employees of the Kuzet-Chimmontazh company gathered outside the firm's office on Tsemzavodskaya street in Shymkent demanding back pay which the company owes them since 2017. [size=10-15]

On 8 February 2020, about 200 protesters gathered near the town of Masanchi demanding their fellow villagers to be released from detention after deadly clashes on 7 February in the area. Massive police presence was reported at the protest location. Governor of the Zhambyl region met with protesters and told them their fellow villagers were released. [size=about 200]

On 8 February 2020, about 30 protesters gathered at the Barakholka market in Almaty city in support of the Kazakh rioters that have clashed with Dungan minority in Masanchi village of Korday district leaving 10 mostly Dungan community members killed and forced up to 24000 Dungan population flee to the neighboring Kyrgyzstan. [size=about 30]

On 7 February 2020, violent clashes broke out between dozens of Kazakh and ethnic Dungan villagers in the town of Aukhatty in Korday district of Zhambyl region. No further information. Initial riot which triggered massive violence took place in the village of Masanchi which then spread to Aukhatty. [size=dozens]

On 7 February 2020, ethnic conflict broke out between dozens of Kazakh and ethnic Dungan villagers in the village of Bular Batyr which is next to the town of Masanchi where clashes have been reported first. No further information. [size=dozens]

On 7 February 2020, 10-15 workers of the cleaning company gathered at one of the airport terminals in Nur-Sultan city to protest against deteriorating working conditions. Workers warned the company of upcoming strike if management continues its policy of not providing accessories for work and medical masks which protesters complained have to purchase for their own money. [size=10-15]

On 7 February 2020, a group of people from the ethnic Dungan community reportedly beat up a police officer after their relative's car was stopped and fined, in the village of Sortobe, in Korday district of Zhambyl region. Two Dungan villagers were later detained for assaulting police officers. This is thought to be one of the triggers of the ethnic conflict in Masanchi village of the same district on February 7, where 10 Dungans were killed in a riot. [size=no report]

On 7 February 2020, about 20 mortgage borrowers protested near the Akorda presidential administration in Nur Sultan city, demanding a meeting with the president of Kazakhstan to resolve their concerns with their mortgages. Protesters complained their banks aren't complying with the state initiated refinancing program for borrowers. [size=about 20]

On 7 February 2020, more than 10 ambulance drivers gathered at the regional emergency response service's office in Kazybek Bi district of Karaganda city demanding pay raise and improved working conditions from the Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan. Drivers were dismayed by the fact that their salaries haven't changed from 1 January 2020 unlike medical workers whose salaries were raised on the Health officials directive. [size=more than 10]

On 7 February 2020, inter-ethnic riots took place after the Kazakh residents attacked the Dungan Muslim population in Sortobe town, Korday district, Zhambyl region. Many shops and houses were burnt down during the riots. No further information. The attacks took place as a part of the larger riots in nearby village Masanchi where violence involving Dungan and Kazakh villagers. [size=unknown]

On 7 February 2020, inter-ethnic riots took place after the Kazakh residents attacked the Dungan Muslim population in the villages of Alkoty and Bulakboty near the town of Sortobe in Korday district of Zhambyl region. Many shops and houses were burnt down during the riots. No further information. The attacks took place as a part of the larger riots in nearby village Masanchi where violence involving Dungan and Kazakh villagers. [size=unknown]

On 7 February 2020, 20-30 protesters gathered outside the court in Almaty city demanding freedom to the imprisoned Kazakh woman who was previously sentenced to 8 years in prison for alleged embezzlement on a criminal complaint filed by the Chinese company operating in Kazakhstan. Protesters called for the public to monitor the Chinese companies operating in the country and report any illegal activities the Chinese firms commit. [size=20-30]

On 7 February 2020, clashes broke out after about 300 Kazakh residents attacked the ethnic Dungan community in the town of Masanchi in Korday district of Zhambyl region. It was unclear what sparked the violence, which pitted ethnic Kazakhs against Dungans, a Muslim group of Chinese origin. Many shops and houses were burnt down during the riots that spread to nearby Alkoty, Bulakboty, Aukhatty, Bular Batyr villages and Sortobe town. Police intervened and arrested 47 people including 2 with hunting rifles. Over 40 people and two police officers were injured. Minister of Interior reported that 8 people have been killed and several dozens more wounded as a result. On February 9, the number of death increased to 10. The clashes also led several thousand Dungans to flee to Kyrgyzstan temporarily. [size=300]

On 5 February 2020, 2 ethnic Dungan and 4 Kazakh villagers were involved in a road rage incident resulting in a violent physical confrontation on the Masanchi-Sortobe road near the village of Masanchi in Korday district of Zhambyl region in Kazakhstan. Brawl between the villagers ended with hospitalization of a Kazakh senior man who had a broken leg injury. Kazakh Deputy Interior Minister confirmed on 9 February 2020 that this incident also contributed the spark of the inter-ethnic violence in the ethnic Dungan villages on 7 February. [size=5-6]

On 5 February 2020, about 30 mortgage borrowers gathered outside the Akorda presidential administration in Nur-Sultan city demanding a meeting with the former and incumbent presidents of Kazakhstan regarding their banks that are not complying with the refinancing program. [size=about 30]

On 5 February 2020, 5-6 protesters demonstrated outside the Taskala disrict court in the town of Taskala demanding fair court hearing involving their fellow villager. Villager complained his court case was a result of the improper police investigation. [size=5-6]

On 5 February 2020, about 30 residents of the town of Makat in Atyrau region gathered at the local gasoline station in Makat town demanding the owning company to re-open the station. Protesters addressed their demands with the local administration which assured the locals that it will be open in March 2020. [size=about 30]

On 5 February 2020, 10-15 women protesters gathered outside the Almaty regional administration office in Taldykorgan city demanding that the families receive child subsidies until children turn 7 years old, regardless of the family size . Almaty regional administration declined to meet women advising them to address their concerns with the Mayor's office in Taldykorgan city. [size=10-15]

On 5 February 2020, 4 Kazakh activists including a prominent female activist protested in Nur-Sultan city calling for the European Parliament members to monitor human rights violations in Kazakhstan. [size=4]
On 5 February 2020, about 7 Kazakh activists staged pickets in Almaty city demanding release of all political prisoners from the penitentiary facilities in Kazakhstan. [size=about 7]

On 4 February 2020, dozens of LPG station operators gathered outside the Mangystau regional administration's office in Aktau city demanding equal distribution of the natural gas supply. Protesters complained about 50 LPG retail operators were forced to close businesses due to lack of LPG supply. [size=dozens]

On 4 February 2020, about 300 villagers protested against the land auction of 50000 hectares at the Aiyrtau district administration's office in Saulmakol town. Protesters demanded immediate halt to the auction due to widespread opposition to it in the area. [size=about 300]
On 4 February 2020, about 12 hospital medics in Kentau city protested against the senior hospital management due to salaries cut. [size=about 12]

On 4 February 2020, about 20 mortgage borrowers from across Kazakhstan gathered outside the Ministries building on Mengilik El street in Nur-Sultan city demanding president hears them out on refinancing issues and reforming the country's court system. Protesters called for the Kazakh authorities write off their debt loans. [size=about 20]

On 4 February 2020, more than 10 railroad workers protested against the unsafe working conditions at the Zhanaarka Locomotiv Depot in the town of Atasu. Protesters accused the senior management of negligence. [size=more than 10]

On 4 February 2020, 20-30 activists gathered outside the Mangystau regional court building in Aktau city demanding release of the local blogger from prison who was imprisoned on libel charges. [size=20-30]

On 3 February 2020, about 50 protesters demonstrated outside the Mangystau regional administration's office in Aktau city demanding equal distribution of natural gas to the stations that serve the cars powered with natural gas. [size=about 50]

On 3 February 2020, 20-30 residents of Karkara village protested near the district administration's office in Kegen town against unfair distribution of the pasture land for the farming communities in the area. Protesters complained they have cattle to feed but no land to let their cattle graze on. [size=20-30]

On 31 2020, about 100 car owners protested outside the regional administration's office in Atyrau city demanding free registration of their automobiles in Kazakhstan. Protesters refuse to pay for the registration fees which the country's law requires. [size=about 100]

On 31 January 2020, more than 100 car owners gathered at the sports stadium in Petropavl city demanding the Kazakh authorities ease up on the mandatory registration of cars from the Eurasian Union member states. [size=more than 100]

On 31 January 2020, about 150 car owners gathered outside the city administration's office in Shymkent city to protest against the law which requires them to register their foreign bought automobiles in Kazakhstan. [size=about 150]

On 31 January 2020, about 100 car owners demonstrated outside the regional administration's office in Aktobe city against the law requiring automobiles that were purchased in Armenia, Kyrgyzstan or Russia mandatorily registered in Kazakhstan. Protesters urged the government to grant amnesty and legalization for such vehicles due to unaffordability of fees for registration. [size=about 100]

On 31 January 2020, about 15 car owners gathered on the Abai square in Uralsk city to protest the new law which requires Kazakh citizens who bought automobiles in Armenia, Kyrgyzstan and Russia to register their vehicles mandatorily in Kazakhstan. [size=about 15]

On 31 January 2020, about 80 car owners gathered on the Respublika square in Almaty city demanding the Kazakh authorities register their vehicles without fees and additional charges. Protesters said an extension of registration until next year is not a solution to the issue. [size=about 80]
