On 19 November 2019, 40-50 supporters of 4 Kazakh activists demonstrated outside the Almalinsky district court in Almaty city in solidarity with them. The court sentenced the activists to probation and community service. Meanwhile, 3 Kazakh activists staged a picket at the Respublika square in Almaty city to support the detained activists. Protesters called for a stop to the persecution of activists in Kazakhstan. [size=40-50]

On 18 November, 40-50 parents gathered at a high school in Taraz in protest of the school leadership neglecting the children's safety following the rape of a 12 year old school girl in 15 November. Parents demanded resignation of the director, his deputy and security dispatcher. [size=40-50]

On 18 November, several people attempted to disrupt a meeting of the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan supporters in Kyzylorda city with banners and slogans against the party. After that, DPK organizers continued the meeting at the private house in the same city. [size=several]

On 16 November 2019, about 5 demonstrators staged a counter protest against the Democratic Party of Kazakhstan outside its building in Shymkent where supporters of DPK planned a meeting. DPK activists suspected the counter protest was organized by the Kazakh authorities to disrupt the DPK gathering and discourage supporters from joining the yet unregistered party. [size=about 5]

On 15 November, about 30 activists protested outside the Almalinsky district court in Almaty city in support of political activists whose trials are underway. Protesters called for release of all political prisoners from jails and stop to persecution of activists in Kazakhstan. [size=about 30]

On 14 November, 10-15 supporters and relatives of a missing Kazakh activist protested at the Ministry of Interior demanding full disclosure of his whereabouts. Kazakh Police had stated the day before that an activist broke out of detention facility at the end of his administrative arrest for taking part in protests. [size=10-15]

On 14 November 2019, about 10 protesters rallied in Almaty city urging the authorities to provide more info on whereabouts of a missing Kazakh activist. Protesters called for dismissal of the chief of the national security service and stop to political persecution in Kazakhstan. [size=about10]

On 13 November 2019, about 10 women protested outside the Almaty regional administration's office in Taldykorgan township against social aid delays demanding the authorities provide them with child subsidies and financial support on time. [size=about 10]

On 13 November 2019, about 20 female protesters demonstrated in the town of Ushtobe in Karatalskiy district of Almaty region demanding their child and social subsidies after two months-long delays. Protesters appealed to the country's president for help. [size=about 20]

On 13 November, 20-30 protesters rallied outside the Almalinsky district court in Almaty city demanding release of several Kazakh activists. Protesters called for stop to political persecution in Kazakhstan. [size=20-30]

On 13 November 2019, 20-30 women protested at the Labour and Social Protection department in the city of Atyrau against cancellation of social subsidies to their households demanding the authorities provide financial support with interruptions. [size=20-30]

On 12 November 2019, about 30 residents of Zhaksy township in Zhaksy district of Aqmola region protested against Manganese mining project demanding the local authorities cancel the project out of environmental concerns in the village. [size=about 30]

On 12 November 2019, about 30 protesters gathered outside the provincial court in Turkestan city demanding release of a Kazakh journalist from prison. The Committee to Protect Journalists global watchdog had previously urged the authorities in Kazakhstan to drop all charges against the journalist and free him. [size=about30]

On 11 November 2019, several protesters including a Kazakh journalist demonstrated at the Republic square in Almaty city demanding release of political prisoners from prisons in Kazakhstan. The journalist urged Kazakh citizens to come out for support. [size=several]

On 9 November, 50-60 Oyan Kazakhstan youth group protesters demonstrated by the statue of Abai in Almaty city against authoritarian rule and government in Kazakhstan. Protesters demanded political reforms and switching to parliamentary republic. [size=50-60]

On 9 November, about 50 Respublika movement protesters gathered at the Jerquyik park in Nur-Sultan city demanding reforms and curb to China's growing economic influence in Kazakhstan. Protesters urged the Kazakh authorities to initiate real reforms in the country. [size=about50]

On 9 November, about 10 protesters demonstrated near Sary-Arka movie theater in Almaty city to raise awareness on the rights of workers and Unions in Kazakhstan. Protesters expressed concerns for poor treatment of workers by employers in the country. [size=about10]

On 7 November 2019, 10-15 pre-school program educators protested outside the Saken Seifullin school in the town of Shu of Shuskiy district in Zhambyl region against the planned shutdown of the program demanding a principal keep the program open out of concerns for looming job losses for about fifty employees. [size=10-15]

On 7 November 2019, 10-15 people gathered for the anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution and demonstrated near the rebar plant in Uralsk city. Protesters have expressed their frustration with deteriorating living conditions and political rights in Kazakhstan. [size=10-15]

On 6 November, about 30 protesters rallied outside the Almalinsky district court in Almaty city in support of the Kazakh activists that are on trial. Protesters demanded their freedom and stop to persecution of activists by the authorities. [size=about30]

On 5 November 2019, about 10 laid-off workers of the Bukhtarma cement plant in Oktyabrsky township of Zyryan district in East Kazakhstan region protested outside the plant against unexpected mass lay off demanding an explanation from the management and calling for the country's president and local authorities to get involved in the dispute. [size=about 10]

On 4 November 2019, 5-10 parents protested in Ust-Kamenogorsk city against the privatisation of the local daycare facility demanding their children remain in the state-run pre-school education institution categorically opposing private care out of concerns for poor quality service. [size=5-10]

On 4 November, about 50 farmer protesters rallied on main square in Aktobe city demanding subsidiary support from the state amid financial burdens among the farmer community in Kazakhstan. Protesters urged the Kazakh authorities to resolve the land distribution system in the country. [size=about50]

On 4 November, 3 protesters protested outside the EU Office in Nur-Sultan city urging the EU to address the human rights concerns in Kazakhstan with the Kazakh authorities. Protesters demanded the Kazakh government to release political prisoners from prisons. [size=3]

On 4 November 2019, about 15 residents of Arys township in Turkistan region protested outside their incompletely restored homes against the construction delay which has yet to resume as the winter season is right around the corner. Protesters complained they can't move back in since their partially destroyed or damaged by ammunition depot explosion houses require more work. [size=about 15]

On 4 November 2019, 15-20 activists rallied outside the Police detention facility in Almaty city calling for release of political prisoners in Kazakhstan. Some of the activists have been detained previously and came out of detention to join the protest immediately after release. [size=15-20]

On 3 November, several workers in Shaikoryk town of Jambyl district protested due to unpaid work and two of the protesting workers threatened to commit a suicide if their demands aren't met. Police forces intervened to stop these workers. Pay dispute was resolved after last minute negotiations with a contractor who compensated the workers. [size=several]

On 1 November 2019, resident of Karaganda gathered to raise their voices against alleged closing of a local clinic. They were angered by a notice on the door that the clinic is closing down. [size=no report]

On 1 November, about 10 protesters and representatives of the Ata Just Eriktileri rights group protested outside the China's Consulate in Almaty city. Protesters demanded Chinese government to allow ethnic Kazakhs to visit their relatives in Xinjiang and release all ethnic Kazakhs in China from the internment camps. [size=about 10]

On 1 November, about 7 protesters rallied outside the EU Office in Nur-Sultan city urging the EU force Kazakhstan implement the EU and UN recommendations on human rights in the country. Protesters urged Kazakh government to release political prisoners. [size=about 7]

On 31 October, 50-100 Kazakh oil workers launched a strike at the North Buzachi oil field project and protested demanding wage increase. China's Sinopec company subsidiary refused to raise salaries according to striking workers. [size=50-100]

On 30 October 2019, residents of Pavlodar protested a planned construction in the neighborhood stadium. The locals claimed that children and sportsmen need the stadium. They attempted to interfere with the construction works. Police detained one individual. [size=no report]

On 29 October 2019, about 10 residents of the Asar-2 neighbourhood in Shymkent city protested against the installation of the wireless carrier company's communications antenna and equipment in the neighbourhood demanding the company take it elsewhere due to public health concerns. [size=about 10]

On 29 October, about 100 protesters at the Saryarka dictrict court in Nur-Sultan city demanded release of a Kazakh activist. Lawyers of the activist disagreed with the judge ruling on the case. [size=about 100]

On 26 October, supporters of DVK attempted to hold a protest in Shymkent, but were intercepted by police and several protesters were arrested. DVK called for public demonstrations earlier in October after it was banned by the government. [size=at least several]

On 26 October, supporters of DVK attempted to hold a protest in Aktobe, but were intercepted by police and 10 protesters were arrested. DVK called for public demonstrations earlier in October after it was banned by the government. [size=at least 10]

On 26 October, 10-15 protesters rallied in Almaty city against the economic expansion of China and demanding release of political prisoners in Kazakhstan. Demonstration was conducted later in the day after mass arrests midday and afternoon at the protests nationwide in the country. [size=10-15]

On 26 October, supporters of DVK attempted to hold a protest in Nur-Sultan, but were intercepted by police and 20 protesters were arrested. DVK called for public demonstrations earlier in October after it was banned by the government. [size=at least 20]

On 26 October, supporters of DVK attempted to hold a protest in Almaty, but were intercepted by police and 15-20 protesters were arrested. DVK called for public demonstrations earlier in October after it was banned by the government. [size=at least 15-20]
Police Forces of Kazakhstan (2019-) National Security Committee

On 25 October, several Kazakh activists were detained and some were attacked in Almaty city by the Kazakh security service agents. One of the activists was rushed to hospital after sustaining injuries.
On 24 October, 6 residents gathered to protest against inaccessible public transport near the city administration in Talgar. [size=6]

On 23 October 2019, 40-50 delivery drivers of the bakery protested outside the company's office in Almaty city against low pay and poor working conditions demanding raise and improved working environment or else employees threatened the company with the strike. [size=40-50]

On 23 October 2019, about 30 residents of Okzhetpes village in Burabay district of Akmola region protested against lack of heating supply in their homes demanding the local authorities fix the issue, or else protesters refuse to pay their utility bills for breach of service. [size=about 30]

On 22 October 2019, 20-30 residents of Shelek village in Enbekshikazakh district of Almaty region protested near the Almaty-Khorgos highway against excessive fines and toll fees demanding the authorities grant free access to the freeway and remove fines from their driving records. [size=20-30]

On 19 October, about 250 protesters rallied in Nur-Sultan against domestic violence in Kazakhstan. Organizers urged public to join efforts to make sure women and children feel safe in the country. [size=about 250]

On 19 October, about 80 protesters came to a meeting with the city administration officials to rally against the road construction project. Protesters disagreed with the city plan to build a bridge and road through the city park. [size=about 80]
On 18 October, 10 women protested over delay of social subsidies for households with large families in Kaskelen. Kazakh officials explained delay was caused by insufficient budget funds. [size=10]

On 17 October 2019, 5-10 disabled residents and their relatives protested outside the city labour and social services department in Kyzylorda city demanding their disability pay and benefits on time which protesters complained is impeding with their care providers. [size=5-10]

On 16 October, up to 20 protesters gathered outside the city court demanding release of the local activist in Zhanaozen. Protesters called for authorities to preserve arrested his rights. An activist was sentenced to 5 years in prison on 17 October by Zhanaozen city court. [size=up to 20]

On 16 October, 50-100 Union workers demonstrated outside the local administration in Zhanaozen demanding stop to harassment and intimidation of Unions. Protesters urged the Kazakh authorities to let Unions manage their own affairs. [size=50-100]

On 15 October, 15-20 residents of Uralsk announced creation of the initiative group in protest against the city administration's plan to build a road through a city park. Activists urged others to join the group and stop the project. [size=15-20]

On 15 October, 3 female protesters demanded a meeting with a chief of the presidential administration to address their social problems in Nur-Sultan. Police detained one of the female protesters after a warning. [size=3]

On 14 October, more than 10 female protesters demonstrated outside the regional administration in Turkestan demanding their social assistance subsidies to be paid on time. Kazakh authorities promised to resolve the issue with delays. [size=more than 10]

On 14 October 2019, about 20 tenants of the residential building protested outside their homes in Aktobe city against the lack of heating supply in the building demanding the city authorities fix the issue. [size=about 20]
On 14 October, more than 10 protesters demonstrated addressing their social problems and unemployment in Zhanaozen. Protesters demanded local officials to resolve their problems. [size=more than 10]
On 14 October, more than 30 protesters organized a rally demanding back pay from a company in Almaty. Protesters demanded their salaries from November 2018 to May 2019. [size=more than 30]

On 12 October, a protest was organized by 3 activists in Almaty city in support of political prisoners. It is known that later these activists were detained (but not during the protest) and sentenced to fines and up to 10 days of detention for participation in the protest. [size=3]

On 11 October 2019, around 60 street traders came to Akimat of Shymkent and demanded a meeting with the Akim. They were asking to give them some time to sell their products and not to kick them out of their spots, even though they acknowledged that trading there is illegal. [size=around 60]

On 11 October, workers of the Chinese oil service company in western Kazakhstan protested outside the company office in Aktobe demanding wage increase by 20 percent. Protesters accused the company of failing to raise salaries as agreed previously. [size=no report]
On 11 October, about 200 oil workers in Algabas staged a protest and strike over unpaid wages for 3 months. They demanded the company pay their salaries in full. [size=about 200]

On 11 October 2019, 30-40 relatives and supporters of five convicted police officers protested outside the city court in Kokshetau city demanding retrial of their family members' cases accusing the authorities of fabricating evidence against imprisoned police officers. [size=30-40]

On 11 October, a group of protesters rallied outside the commerce chamber's office in Aktobe demanding the authorities bring back subsidies to the farming businesses in the country. They warned end of subsidies may lead to closure of businesses. [size=no report]

On 11 October, about a dozen protesters in Aktobe protested against corruption in Kazakhstan. Demonstrators raised the issue of bribery and payments in the country's education sector. [size=about a dozen]

On 9 October 2019, 10-15 residents of Kostogan village in Merki district of Zhambyl region protested against the lack of water supply in the village demanding the local administration provides a steady supply of water in the area. [size=10-15]

On 9 October, about 100 oil-worker protesters gathered outside the local administration in western Zhanaozen rallying against the state-owned oil and gas company subsidiary's management. Protesters demanded the local administration intervene in the conflict between union and management. [size=about 100]

On 8 October 2019, about 50 supporters of an imprisoned Kazakh journalist gathered in Shymkent to show solidarity and support. His lawyer argued a court case was one-sided and rights were violated. [size=about 50]

On 8 October, 10 protesters resisted against forced eviction of a household by the bank in Almaty city. Arrived Kazakh national bank official defused the conflict after intervening in eviction process. [size=10]

On 8 October, rioters attacked the Chinese workers of CITIC Construction in Aksu after brawl a day earlier between Chinese workers and a Kazakh citizen. Several Chinese nationals were hospitalized in the aftermath of mob violence and several Kazakh nationals were detained. 42 Chinese citizens were deported in the aftermath of the violent brawl due to their illegal immigration status which doesn't allow to work in Kazakhstan. [size=no report]

On 8 October 2019, about 20 residents of Sharapkhana village in Turkistan region protested against the town administration's inability to fix the local drinking water infrastructure and provide villagers with clean water. [size=about 20]

On 7 October, dozens of Kazakh protesters rallied in Aksu against Chinese CITIC Construction managers over mistreatment and unsatisfactory working conditions. They urged the Kazakh authorities to intervene in the conflict between Chinese management and Kazakh personnel. [size=dozens]

On 6 October 2019, dozens of ambulance medical personnel protested in Saryagash against the deterioration of working conditions. They urged the Kazakh authorities to pay attention to the aging ambulance fleet, wages and ban on union membership. [size=dozens]

On 3 October 2019, about 10 residents of Usharal village in Alakol district of Almaty region protested against lack of drinking water supply in town demanding the local administration fix the water supply infrastructure. [size=about 10]

On 2 October 2019, about 20 veterans of the Soviet-Afghan war protested in Almaty city at the Memorial dedicated to the fallen Soviet troops in Afghanistan against Kazakh journalist Marat Tokashbayev's earlier remarks on TV which protesters deemed hurtful and inappropriate demanding his apology. [size=about 20]

On 2 October 2019, 10-15 female residents of Arys township in Turkistan region protested outside the Mayor's office demanding compensation for the possible environmental and public health problems among fellow residents after ammunition depot explosion months earlier. [size=10-15]

On 1 October 2019, about 20 residents of Bulak village in Esil district of North Kazakhstan region protested against the nearby Auliye Gold Mining project accusing it in contaminating local spring and alleging spike in cancer diseases and death cases among fellow villagers because of the project's negative environmental impact. [size=about 20]

On 1 October, 5-10 protesters rallied in Almaty city demanding the country's banks to adjust their lending practices. They urged the banks to write-off mortgages to the orphaned children among listed demands. [size=5-10]

Around 1 October 2019, 15-20 workers of the Emir-Oil exploration company protested at the work camp near the city of Aktau in Mangystau region demanding pay raise by fifty percent and calling for the country's new president Tokayev to intervene in their labour dispute with the company. [size=15-20]

On 1 October 2019, about 30 female protesters marched through downtown Nur-Sultan city to demonstrate near the Akorda presidential administration demanding a meeting with the country's former president Nursultan Nazarbayev to address social aid to households with multiple children. [size=about 30]

On 30 September, more than 3 protesters demonstrated outside the court building in Uralsk demanding fair trial for their family members. Protesters accused the Kazakh law enforcement of fabricating criminal cases against their relatives. [size=more than 3]

On 29 September, protesters gathered in Almaty declaring their support to the protesters in Hong-Kong and demanding to stop the alleged Chinese expansion in the country; support of minorities in China was also voiced. About 50 protesters reportedly participated. [size=about 50]

On 29 September, protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), declaring their support to the protesters in Hong-Kong and demanding to stop the alleged Chinese expansion in the country; support of minorities in China was also voiced. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]
Women (Kazakhstan); KazFem: Feminist Initiative Group of Kazakhstan

On 28 September, dozens of protesters, predominantly women, gathered for the first-ever sanctioned feminist rally in Almaty. The protesters demanded gender equality and support of women. The event was organized by the KazFem group. [size=dozens]
On 27 September, a large crowd from Shymkent, predominantly bikers, gathered near the police to support a detained social activist. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=large crowd]

On 27 September 2019, about 10 female residents of the town of Arys in Turkistan region gathered near the local town hospital to raise their concerns regarding public health and environmental risks in the area after ammunition depot explosion months before demanding the authorities provide their households with compensation. On 27 September 2019, 10-15 students of the Taraz State Pedagogical University protested outside campus in Taraz township against the incorporation of the university with the State University The protesters complained, that it may reduce the quality of education and downgrade their diploma degrees. On 26 September, a group of international students of the Kazakh origin gathered in Astana (Nursultan) in the office of the ruling party Nur-Otan, calling for support and assistance. On 25 September 2019, about 15 residents of Khromtau village in Khromtau district of Aktobe region protested against lack of drinking water and natural gas supply in the village demanding the district authorities resolve the issue. [size=about 15]

On 24 September 2019, 50-100 workers of the Chinese company protested near their work camps at the Karakuduk oil project in Mangystau region demanding pay raise. [size=50-100]

On 23 September 2019, about 10 victims of a fraudulent housing scheme protested outside the Aktobe regional prosecutor's office in Aktobe city demanding the law enforcement agency arrest perpetrator, recover their funds and serve justice after the city court judge let alleged fraud mastermind walk free without arraignment. On 23 September, a policeman reportedly attacked and severely wounded a resident of Uralsk; the man later died in hospital. In two days the policeman was arrested and put into a detention facility for further investigation. The reason for the attack was not revealed.

On 21 September 2019, 20-30 protesters demonstrated in Aktau city against the construction of the factories in Kazakhstan by China demanding the Kazakh government roll back Chinese investments in the country. [size=20-30]

On 21 September, rallies of the opposition were held in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Aktobe. Law enforcers reportedly started detaining protesters immediately, detaining dozens. The exact number of protesters was not reliably revealed. [size=no report]

On 21 September, around 10-15 protesters demonstrated against China's economic expansion in Kyzylorda city. Police warned protesters of legal liabilities due to unsanctioned nature of the rally. [size=around 10-15]

On 10 September, about a dozen of sole protesters with pickets gathered for the second day in one street in Astana (Nursultan). On 9 September 2019, 40-50 construction workers protested outside the Shar Kurylys company's office in Nur-Sultan city, demanding their wages for four months of work. [size=40-50]

On 7 September, about 30 protesters gathered in Atyrau, protesting against economic expansion of China in the country. [size=about 30]

On 7 September, several dozen protesters gathered in Almaty, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=several dozen]

On 7 September, about 50 protesters gathered in Aktobe near a local court. They protested against alleged unjust verdict over law enforcers, convicted of torture, and demanded an appeal against the sentence. [size=about 50]
On 7 September, unidentified attackers were throwing stones at Uzbek trucks parked near Atyrau and damaged them. It was reported that only vehicles with Uzbek plates were attacked.

On 6 September 2019, about 20 workers of the Chinese managed cement production plant protested outside the plant in the town of Shieli against the poor working conditions at work and demanded to raise the salaries. [size=about 20]

On 6 September 2019, more than 5 protesters demonstrated near the city administration's office in Kostanay city against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan. Protesters expressed their support to the fellow protesters in Zhanaozen city where anti-China protests were staged first. [size=more than 5]

On 6 September 2019, dozens of oil workers of the Chinese company protested at their work station near North Buzachi oil field in Mangystau region against discrimination of the Kazakh workers by the Chinese company and demanded raise and equal pay for Kazakh workers. [size=dozens]

On 6 September 2019, about 20 women and problematic mortgage holders protested at the city administration's office in Nur-Sultan city demanding the city authorities to resolve their concerns regarding targeted social subsidies for households with multiple children and high-interest rate mortgages for women and single mothers in Kazakhstan. [size=about 20]

On 6 September 2019, about 5 female protesters demonstrated at the Mayor's office in Shymkent city demanding a meeting with the city official. Protesters complained the administration ignored their calls for four days which forced them to stage a protest inside the Mayor's office. [size=about 5]

On 5 September, several protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=several]

On 5 September, about 20 protesters gathered in Almaty, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. Furthermore, they demanded release of political prisoners, related to the support of Muslims in China. [size=about 20]

On 5 September 2019, 10-15 protesters demonstrated near the monument to Aliya Moldagulova, Manshuk Mametova and Hiuza Dospanova in Uralsk city against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan. Protesters expressed their solidarity with fellow protesters in Zhanaozen city. [size=10-15]

On 5 September 2019, 20-25 protesters demonstrated in Shymkent city against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan demanding the country's government cancel an investment deal with China. Protesters called for the authorities not to let the Chinese businesses in the country under no circumstances. [size=20-25]

On 5 September 2019, about 50 residents of Aktobe city demonstrated near the Aktobe regional administration's office against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan. [size=about 50]

On 5 September 2019, 40-50 residents of Zhanaozen city protested near the city administration's office against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan. [size=40-50]

On 4 September 2019, several activists marched through the business district of Semey city protesting against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan. Protesters expressed their solidarity with fellow anti-China protesters in Zhanaozen city. [size=no report]

On 4 September, protesters gathered in Uralsk, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2019, 15-20 predominantly female protesters gathered outside the presidential administration in Astana (Nur-Sultan), demanding an apology from one of the MPs, who had allegedly insulted them by his comments regarding the public social support for large families and mothers with disabled children. Protesters demanded 42500 Tenge social subsidy for every child regardless of the family's social status. [size=15-20]

On 4 September, about 50 protesters gathered in Aktobe, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 50]

On 4 September 2019, about 30 protesters gathered in Shymkent, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 30]

On 4 September, about a dozen of protesters gathered in Karaganda, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about a dozen]

On 4 September, protesters gathered in Aktau, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]

On 4 September, several residents of Ust-Kamenogorsk went for a picket protest against the expansion of China in the country. The organizer was later fined for the unauthorized protest, which was later changed to three days of administrative arrest. [size=several]

On 4 September, dozens of protesters gathered in Almaty, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=dozens]

On 4 September 2019, about 10 female protesters demonstrated at the local labour and social protection department in Kyzylorda city against labour official demanding his resignation due to poor performance. Protesters filed a petition addressing it to the country's president for intervention in the case. [size=about 10]

On 4 September, about 30 protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 30]

On 4 September 2019, 10-15 parents of female students protested near high school in the village of Firdausi in Maktaraal district of Turkistan region against official ban on wearing hijab by students in the school which protesters complained is discriminatory toward the local Muslim community. [size=10-15]

On 4 September 2019, about 15 residents of Kyzylorda city protested at the city's main square against China's economic projects and expansion in Kazakhstan expressing their solidarity with fellow protesters in Zhanaozen city. [size=about 15]

On 4 September 2019, several protesters demonstrated near the city administration's office in Taraz city of Zhambyl region against the construction of the factories and other Chinese investment projects in Kazakhstan expressing solidarity with fellow anti-China protesters in Zhanaozen city. [size=no report]

On 3 September 2019, about 30 protesters gathered in Shymkent, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 30]

On 3 September, about 10 protesters gathered in Karaganda, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 10]

On 3 September, about 30 protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=about 30]

On 3 September, several dozen protesters gathered in Almaty, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. [size=several dozen]

On 3 September, protesters gathered in Aktobe, protesting against economic expansion of China in Kazakhstan and expressed their support and solidarity with protesters in Zhanaozen. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]

On 3 September, about 500 protesters gathered near the building of local administration in Zhanaozen, demanding cancellation of President's working visit to China and opposing the proposed governmental plant to establish 55 factories with Chinese financial assistance. [size=about 500]

On 2 September 2019, about a dozen female protesters, predominantly single mothers or those with disabled children, gathered in Shymkent, calling for more efficient social support. [size=about a dozen]

On 2 September 2019, about 15 new homeowners and construction workers protested at the construction site of an unfinished housing project in 7th micro-district of Taldykorgan township in Almaty region demanding the developer company complete the apartment building on schedule and pay owed wages to its workers. [size=about 15]

On 2 September, about 100 male protesters gathered near the building of the local administration in Zhanaozen, demanding cancellation of the President's working visit to China and opposing the proposed governmental plan to establish 55 factories with Chinese financial assistance. [size=about 100]

On 1 September 2019, about 5 protesters demonstrated in Nur-Sultan city against the persecution of three female activists demanding the authorities drop charges against them and release fellow activists from detention. [size=about 5]

On 30 August, a group of activists gathered in Astana (Nursultan), calling for a reform of the constitution and of the election system. According to the photo provided, around seven individuals gathered. [size=around seven]

On 30 August, about a dozen of protesters gathered in Shymkent, calling for democratic reforms and honoring constitutional rights for holding peaceful assemblies and freedom of expression. The movement Oyan, Qazaqstan organized the event. [size=about a dozen]

On 30 August, dozens of protesters gathered in Almaty, calling for democratic reforms and honoring constitutional rights for holding peaceful assemblies and freedom of expression. The movement Oyan, Qazaqstan organized the event. Law enforcers were present but did not interfere. [size=dozens]

On 29 August, an activist in Astana (Nursultan) and her supporters gathered to hold a picket to honor the memory of victims of the Semipalatinsk nuclear test site and to demand compensations for them. According to the photo provided around a dozen of protesters participated. [size=around a dozen]

On 28 August 2019, about 10 homebuyers set up several tents outside the construction site of their unfinished apartment building in Vostochka neighbourhood of Almaty city in protest of delay demanding the developer company refund their mortgage deposits or else deliver their housing project on time. [size=about 10]

On 28 August, law enforcers in Almaty asked several leaders of the movement Oyan Kazakhstan to come to the police station, where representatives of the local administration threatened them and warned them not to attend a planned rally on 30th August. Some of them were taken from their homes, one was called even from a hospital. The activists claimed that such pressure is illegal and the rally is going to happen anyway.

On 27 August 2019, about a dozen activists held picket protests in Almaty, demanding the release of alleged political prisoners and jailed activists. Later they dispersed. Similarly, residents of Almaty held a rally near the local branch of the International Bureau for Human Rights, demanding the resignation of the head of the local police department. According to the photo provided, about a dozen protesters gathered. [size=dozens]

On 26 August, about a dozen of protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan). They were predominantly parents and other family members of disabled children, complaining of inefficiency of the state housing program. [size=about a dozen]

On 26 August 2019, about 20 residents of Borankul village in Beyneu district of Mangystau region protested against lack of access to drinking water demanding the district authorities connect their village to the newly installed water supply plant nearby. [size=about 20]

On 26 August, an activist was attacked in Talghar on her way to the building of the local administration - was shot from an air rifle in her leg. Soon, two suspects were detained - an official from a local district and his driver.

On 26 August, several activists held picket protests in Astana (Nursultan), demanding the release of political prisoners. Law enforcers were present but did not interfere. Later they dispersed. [size=several]

On 25 August, about 20 protesters gathered in Shymkent to support political prisoners, namely those arrested and jailed after rallies in 2016. They also criticized the former President Nazarbayev for his critical attitude towards the socioeconomic situation of single mothers and large families. [size=about 20]

On 25 August, 15 activists gathered in Astana (Nursultan) for a satiric artistic protest 'Monstration'. Nine of them were detained by law enforcers and reportedly also their phones were seized from them. Later they were released. [size=15]

On 24 August, five residents of Astana (Nursultan) gathered for a rally near the local police department, demanding return of their phones, laptops and other gadgets, that were seized from three of them during protests in May. They also declared a hunger strike to support their demands. Police later called them inside; protesters refused to enter until the return of their property. Later they were detained and sentenced to various days of an administrative arrest for alleged disobedience of law enforcers. [size=5]

On 23 August, protesters gathered near the embassy of the US in Astana (Nursultan), declaring their support to political prisoners in the country. Law enforcers were present but did not interfere. The exact number of protesters was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 22 August 2019, about 20 homebuyers gathered outside the ruling Nur-Otan party's office in Almaty city demanding their state-financed housing project completed and delivered for residence on schedule which protesters complained the construction company couldn't meet on time. [size=about 20]

On 21 August, the government of Kazakhstan established special prosecutor's commissions for the Almaty district and the Eastern Kazakhstan oblast (Ust-Kamenogorsk) in order to prevent and investigate cases of torture in prisons. The new bodies should monitor all prisons constantly and supervise employees in the facilities. [coded to Almaty]
On 21 August, employers of the company Shymkent Bus gathered for a rally, complaining that they had not received their salaries for two months. Reportedly, over 20 protesters gathered. [size=over 20]

On 21 August 2019, about 10 residents of Zhana Kanayka village in Ulan district of East Kazakhstan region protested against shut down of the local psychiatric clinic due to outdated infrastructure concerns demanding the authorities build a new one. Protesters complained some of them worked at the clinic and expressed worries they may lose jobs. [size=about 10]

On 21 August 2019, about 15 supporters of imprisoned Kazakh activist protested outside the Saryarkinsky district court in Nur-Sultan city demanding to release and drop all charges against him calling it politically motivated persecution. [size=about 15]

On 21 August 2019, 10-15 female protesters gathered at the city labour department in Shymkent city demanding the local authorities provide them with child subsidies after the Kazakh central government rolled back its previous policy to support every household with multiple children in need. The new policy required the eligible family to provide proof of having at least one child with a disability to receive a social subsidy which protesters disagreed with. [size=10-15]

On 20 August, residents of Shymkent whose apartments had burnt down in the beginning of Summer, went to a collective hunger strike. They complained that the local authorities promised to build a new residence for them but their house had been demolished and over 120 individuals had been left homeless without any compensation. The exact number of protesters out of 120 residents was not revealed. [size=no report]
On 19 August, about a dozen of residents of Shymkent gathered for a rally, complaining about the poor quality of local roads and other infrastructure and social services. [size=about a dozen]

On 19 August, a group of bikers arrived to Kostanay to hold a ceremony to commemorate the victory in the WWII; brought flowers to memorials and met with local peers. The event was a part of a large route of bikers across various other cities, dedicated to particular battles, military units or other memories related to the war. The exact number of riders involved was not revealed. The event was organized by the Black knives club, which refers directly to the resistance to the Nazi units. [size=a group]

On 19 August, over 40 protesters, predominantly women, gathered in Astana (Nursultan) demanding better social support to large families and financial assistance related to the beginning of the school year. [size=over 40]

On 19 August, a group of protesters, predominantly women, gathered in Aktobe demanding better social support to large families and financial assistance related to the beginning of the school year. [size=a group]

On 18 August, reportedly four activists held a rally in Almaty, calling for tougher punishment of those who commit sexual violence and to criminalize sexual harassment. Various bystanders approached and debated with them about such sensitive topic emotionally, but no violent clash was reported. [size=4]

On 18 August, a clash emerged among local residents and private security forces guarding the village Maraldy in Pavlodar region over alleged poaching in a lake nearby. Five locals were injured during the brawl, some equipment of the private guards, including a vehicle were reportedly seized. Local residents claimed that the guards had detained one man over alleged poaching and they just had wanted to defend him. [size=no report]

On 18 August, an office of the KazTAG news agency in Almaty was robbed and a computer with sensitive databases and some other data storages were seized. The journalists claimed that it was not a usual robbery, because only some storages had disappeared but other expensive equipment and their belongings had been left, and thus it should be considered as an act against the agency.

On 16 August, protesters gathered in Akmol, demanding immediate release of political prisoners and declaring their support the leader of the movement Volunteers of the Fatherland, who was facing charges at a court. According to the photos provided, about 30 protesters participated. [size=about 30]

On 16 August 2019, 15-20 female residents of Kyzylorda city protested at the local labour department demanding their social and child subsidies on time without further delay. Protesters complained they are unable to send their children back to school in two weeks without child subsidies. [size=15-20]

On 16 August 2019, 10-15 activists protested by the Bayterek Tower in Nur-Sultan city to express their solidarity with ethnic Kazakh rights defender Serikzhan Bilash whose court trial was underway in the Almaty city. [size=10-15]

On 16 August, around a hundred of protesters gathered in Almaty near a courtroom, demanding release of the leader of the organization 'Atazhurt Eriktileri' who was about to face his trial. Law enforcers were present but did not interfere. [size=around a hundred]

On 15 August 2019, more than 5 female protesters gathered at the Nur-Otan party's office in the town of Taldykorgan in Almaty region demanding a meeting with its top official to discuss their social support. [size=more than 5]

On 15 August, several protesters representing people with disabilities gathered in Almaty. They complained of insufficient support from the authorities, especially related to housing. They even declared a hunger strike, if their complaints are not heard. [size=several]

On 14 August 2019, about 10 residents of Karabas town in Abay district of Karagandy region protested against ordered eviction of their families from the Ministry of Defense owned apartment building which protesters refused to do after residing at the address for more than twenty years. Protesters demanded proper compensation for the relocation. [size=about 10]

Around 14 August 2019, about 15 activists protested outside the Karasay district court in the town of Kaskelen in Almaty region against the persecution of their fellow activist demanding the authorities drop charges against him. [size=about 15]

On 13 August 2019, about 15 female protesters gathered at the town administration's office in Kentau township in Turkistan region to protest against mandatory refund of the social subsidy payments back to the state. [size=about 15]

On 12 August 2019, about 20 residents of Arys gathered near the building of the local administration, complaining about allegedly insufficient support and compensation after the recent explosions in a military warehouse nearby. [size=about 20]

On 12 August, about 20 protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan) near embassies of predominantly western countries, calling for release of jailed political prisoners, like the former head of the Kazatomprom nuclear agency. No detentions or interferences of law enforcers were reported. [size=about 20]

On 12 August 2019, several former workers of the Chinese company protested outside the firm's office in Aktobe city demanding their compensation pay for health risk. The protesters complained that they have been trying to recover from the health issues caused by their previous work for more than a year. [size=several]

On 12 August 2019, about 10 residents of the local neighbourhood in the outskirts of Almaty city protested against costly natural gas supply project in the area demanding the authorities bring down the costs and take oversight of the project's safety after complaints about unsafe conditions. [size=about 10]

On 12 August, a massive brawl erupted between local residents of Zhairem, Karaganda region, and foreign workers, located at a construction site nearby. As a result, several workers had to be treated with various injuries. The reason of clashes was not revealed, but seven residents of Zhairem were already detained. [size=no report]

On 10 August 2019, around two dozens protesters gathered for a meeting in Shymkent, declaring their support to a prominent Kazakh activist who focused on issues of ethnic Kazakhs in China and founded the movement Atazhurt Eriktileri (Volunteer of the Fatherland), as he was arrested for his activities. [size=around two dozens]

On 10 August, civil activists gathered in Almaty, declaring their support for individuals considered as political prisoners and collected material support for their families. They announced their aim to repeat such actions each month. Law enforcers were present but did not interfere. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 9 August 2019, about 5 construction workers protested in the town of Arys in Turkistan region demanding their wages. Protesters complained they came from Kyzylorda region to rebuild damaged properties in Arys township after military ammunition warehouse explosion. [size=about 5]

On 8 August, 26 workers at a construction field in Astana (Nursultan) started a collective hunger strike, complaining that they had not received their salaries for nine months. Earlier, they were simply on strike, but their employer did not react, hence decided to tougher their protest this way. [size=26]

On 7 August, protesters with pickets gathered in Astana (Nursultan) and in a minor number in Semey, expressing support to political prisoners and demanding their release. Reportedly about 20 protesters gathered. [size=about 20]

On 7 August, protesters with pickets gathered in Astana (Nursultan) and in a minor number in Semey, expressing support to political prisoners (e.g. the former head of the state company Kazatomprom) and demanding their release. According to the photo provided, around a dozen individuals participated. [size=around a dozen].

On 6 August 2019, about 10 former workers of the Reform Stroy company protested outside its office in Atyrau city against unexpected layoffs which protesters complained came after mass brawl incident at the Chinese CCNP co-managed Tengiz oil field project, previously. Protesters called for the regional governor to step in and deliver on his promise to preserve jobs. [size=about 10]

On 5 August, about three dozen of female protesters, predominantly mothers, gathered in Astana (Nursultan) near the center of local administration, calling for proper housing and other social services for vulnerable and large families and single mothers. The current housing program they found insufficient. [size=about three dozen]

On 5 August, several protesters held a picket protest in Almaty near a building of a court. They protested against punishment of imprisoning imposed on eight individuals for alleged religious-liked crimes. The protesters were predominantly relatives of the defendants. Their exact number was not reported. [size=no report]

Around 5 August 2019, 5-10 activists staged a protest in Shymkent city business district against political persecution of Kazakh politician Moukhtar Zhakishev demanding his release from prison. [size=5-10]

On 4 August 2019, around 15 protesters gathered in Shymkent at a rally, calling for release of political prisoners, including the former head of a state company, who faced charges for an alleged fraud. [size=around 15]

On 4 August, around two dozen of activists gathered in Akmol to declare their support to individuals considered to be political prisoners and members of the opposition, holding photographs of 28 persecuted individuals. There were mostly women among the protesters. [size=around two dozen]
Police Forces of Kazakhstan (2019-) Prison Guards

On 3 August, a mass brawl occurred in Kyzylorda at night. Law enforcers arrived to calm the situation, but were also attacked and injured and were forced to fire warning shots into the air. Following the fight, several individuals were detained. [size=no report]

On 3 August, a planned rally for reform of the Ministry of Internal Affairs was cancelled in Almaty after police forces started summoning the organizers and interrogating them about their alleged links to the banned party Democratic choice of Kazakhstan. They emphasized that they did not belong to the party, but rather cancelled the event as such to avoid further tensions.

On 3 August, a small group of predominantly female protesters gathered in Almaty for a rally 'Freedom to mothers', calling for support of families, where mothers are either detained or kept far from their families for other reason and cannot care for their children in the beginning of the school year. The exact number of protesters was not reported. [size=no report]

On 2 August 2019, about 10 customers of the local brick plant protested outside the plant facility in Shymkent city demanding their funds back or ordered products which they paid for months ago. Protesters complained they might not be able to recover their funds due to possible insolvency concerns. [size=about 10]

On 1 August 2019, 15-20 residents of Shu district in Zhambyl region protested in Shu township against police abuse of power after an incident day earlier involving local fellow villagers and police officers demanding the district police leadership resign due to multiple allegations of police misconduct in the area. [size=15-20]

On 31 July, an angry crowd of approximately 30 individuals surrounded a police convoy in Shu, Zhambyl Oblast. They turned to be relatives and friends of detainees in the police vehicles and the crowd literally tried to release them, but did not succeed. [size=approximately 30]

On 31 July 2019, 15-20 supporters of an imprisoned Kazakh activist, Kayirly Omar, protested at the court in Nur-Sultan city where activist's court hearing took place, demanding to release him. [size=15-20]

On 30 July, a Russian policeman was attacked by a local resident during his attempt to enter the limited-access area of Baikonur (rented to the Russian Federation) from a nearby village Toretam without an official permission. The attacker was later detained and handed over to Kazakh authorities for further investigation.
Police Forces of Kazakhstan (2019-) Prison Guards

As reported on 29 July, videos of torture of prisoners in a Zarechnoye detention facility, Almaty region occurred on the network. Soon, several prison guards and officials were either detained or fired.

On 29 July, dozens of protesters, predominantly women, gathered in a building of local administration in Astana (Nursultan), complaining about ineffectiveness of a local social support and demand a better one. They met with local representatives, who insisted that the current situation is all right. [size=dozens]

On 29 July 2019, about 60 supporters of the leader of Ata-Jurt Eriktileri rights group, Serikzhan Bilash, specializing on ethnic Kazakh human rights in China's Xinjiang region, protested outside the Almatynsky district court in Nur-Sultan city demanding his release and stop the persecution by the Kazakh authorities. [size=about 60]

On 28 July, protesters blocked a local highway in Taldykorgan district, complaining about poor compensation regarding the construction of the highway. Law enforcers arrived and resumed the traffic, claiming that the organizers may be held administratively liable. Reportedly, around 14 protesters gathered. [size=around 14]

On 27 July, a resident of Astana (Nursultan) was reportedly attacked and tortured for his homosexual orientation. Two attackers abducted him, tortured him and demanded names of other LGBT people. Both were later arrested.

On 27 July, about a dozen of protesters gathered in Almaty, calling of immediate release of a jailed former head of a national company. They considered him a political prisoner. Similar expressions of support, mostly single-picket protests, took part at several other cities of Kazakhstan. [size=about a dozen]

On 27 July, an angry crowd attacked an investor of the Maraldy Lake project during a meeting in Sharbakty, where he tried to persuade locals to stop poaching at the lake. Reportedly, representatives of the local administration were present, but did not defend him. [size=no report]

On 26 July 2019, more than 5 residents with disabilities protested outside the Shymkent Plaza shopping centre in Shymkent city against discrimination of disabled citizens and poor accessibility at the mall demanding Plaza management resolve their concerns. [size=more than 5]

On 26 July, about a dozen of protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), calling of immediate release of a jailed former head of a national company. They considered him a political prisoner. Similar expressions of support, mostly single-picket protests, took part in several other cities of Kazakhstan. [size=about a dozen]
On 24 July, a group of disabled people gathered in Shymkent, demanding better social support from the administration. Reportedly, several protesters gathered, no detentions reported. [size=several]

On 24 July 2019, about 15 new homeowners protested outside their apartments in Petropavl city against poor quality construction job on the state-financed housing project and safety issues. [size=about 15]
Police Forces of Kazakhstan (2019-) National Security Committee
On 24 July, a transgender prisoner reported frequent rape in a detention facility for women in Zhaugashty, Almaty region; reportedly by a member of the National Security Committee.

On 23 July, inspectors of a public institution responsible for hunting and hunters in Kazakhstan were attacked by poachers during inspection in the Akmol region [coded to Kokshetau]. One was killed, one wounded. Later, two suspects were detained - a father and his son.

On 23 July 2019, 20-30 female protesters gathered at the local employment department in Kentau township in Turkistan region to express their frustration with the state-required proof of self-employment for women with multiple children. The protesters argued it was impossible to do while having small children to raise at home. [size=20-30]

On 23 July 2019, 5-10 female protesters gathered near the Akorda presidential administration in Nur-Sultan city demanding the country's government tighten child protection laws in Kazakhstan following minor abuse incident in Shymkent city day before. [size=5-10]

On 23 July 2019, about 10 residents of Shaikoryk village in Zhambyl district of Zhambyl region protested against lack of attention from the local administration to the needs of the villagers demanding the authorities address the social and infrastructural issues of the town. [size=about 10]
Women (Kazakhstan); DVK: Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan

On 22 July, a group of women attacked journalists during a press conference in Almaty, related to female rights and economic conditions in Kazakhstan. The attackers demanded the present journalists not to film the event; blocked filming and damaged their equipment. Authorities later claimed that they were members of the Democratic choice of Kazakhstan, the banned party, but this claim has not been confirmed by independent sources [coded as UAG].

On 19 July, around a dozen of mothers of many children or caring about disabled one gathered near the building of local administration in Astana (Nursultan), demanding proper housing and social services to be provided to them by authorities. [size=around a dozen]

On 18 July, a two-days special operation was held in Shymkent, Kyzylorda and Almaty against activities of criminal gangs, organizing large scale smuggling of weapons; some of them were reportedly also followers of radical Islamic religious movements. Various weapons were seized. The exact number of arrested individuals was not revealed.

On 18 July, a two-days special operation was held in Shymkent, Kyzylorda and Almaty against activities of criminal gangs, organizing large scale smuggling of weapons; some of them were reportedly also followers of radical Islamist religious movements. Various weapons were seized. The exact number of arrested individuals was not revealed.

On 18 July, a two-days special operation was held in Shymkent, Kyzylorda and Almaty against activities of criminal gangs, organizing large scale smuggling of weapons; some of them were reportedly also followers of radical Islamist religious movements. Various weapons were seized. The exact number of arrested individuals was not revealed.

On 16 July 2019, 20-30 workers of the Chinese road construction company protested at the field camp office near the town of Aksuat in Tarbagatay district of East Kazakhstan region demanding wages and better working conditions. Protesters warned the company of walkout if their demands aren't met. [size=20-30]
On 16 July 2019, about 15 workers of the bridge construction company Mostotryad-25 protested at the firm's main office in Almaty city demanding back pay for months work. [size=about 15]
On 16 July, dozens of female protesters, predominantly mothers with children, gathered in Almaty, demanding improvements of a social program which they are participating at. [size=dozens]

On 15 July 2019, about 20 female protesters gathered at the regional administration's office in Aktobe city, demanding better social services and housing for single mothers and large families. [size=about 20]

On 14 July, there was a small non-violent dispute between Georgian citizens and military forces of Azerbaijan in Davit Gareja Monastery. The dispute started after Georgians saw icons being taken from the territory of the Monastery. Davit Gareja lies at the undemarked border of Georgia and Azerbaijan. Recently there have been tensions on the site.

On 12 July 2019, dozens of female protesters and mothers of large families gathered in Shymkent near the building of local administration, demanding better social service, especially housing, for large families and families with disabled children. Law enforcers were present, but did not interfere. [size=dozens]

On 12 July, dozens of protesters gathered in Almaty with pickets, declaring their support to a jailed activist and demanding his immediate release from house arrest. No intervention of law enforcers reported. [size=dozens]

On 12 July, dozens of female protesters-mothers of large families, gathered in Astana (Nursultan), demanding better social services, especially housing, for large families and families with disabled children. Some of them tried to enter the building, but police forces stopped them. [size=dozens]

On 11 July 2019, about 15 residents of Sadyr village in Panfilov district of Almaty region protested against lack of access to drinking water in the village demanding the local authorities address their concerns. [size=about 15]

As reported on 11 July, a dead corpse of a local law enforcer was found near Zhaysan village of the Zhambyl region. The man was stabbed and burnt by an unknown attacker. Most likely the reason was related to his professional activities, as his personal belongings were found nearby.
On 10 July 2019, a group of protesters demonstrated against the country's court system demanding the Kazakh authorities revise their court cases due to injustice, protesters claimed. [size=no report]

On 10 July 2019, an unidentified group of attackers rushed into a house of an imam in Sayram and severely beat him in front of his children. Reportedly, they also threatened him, but the reason was not mentioned.

On 10 July, dozens of protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), near the office of the former President Nazarbayev, calling for proper investigation of countermeasures imposed by police forces during the recent demonstrations. [size=dozens]

On 9 July, dozens of protesters gathered in Astana (Nursultan), near the office of the President, calling for proper investigation of countermeasures imposed by police forces during the recent demonstrations. [size=dozens]

On 9 July, about 20 female protesters-mothers of large families, gathered in Aktobe near the building of local administration, demanding better social services, especially housing, for large families and families with disabled children. [size=about 20]

On 9 July 2019, several masked rioters physically assaulted TV journalists at the scene of anti-government demonstration in Nur-Sultan city. Rioters used umbrellas to block cameraman's recording equipment as victims complained police failed to protect them from rioters. [size=several]

On 9 July 2019, about 200 coal mine workers protested at the Shubarkul Coal company's office in Karaganda city against top managers demanding the company executives dismiss mine management after one of their fellow workers committed suicide due to pressure from the management personnel. Protesters warned the company they would strike if their demands aren't met. [size=about 200]

On 6 July, protesters gathered in largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Ust-Kamenogorsk, protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. The exact number of protesters was not revealed but some were reportedly detained. Several of them, mostly activists were later sentenced to several days of administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized in part by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan.[size=no report]

On 6 July 2019, dozens protesters gathered in largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Shymkent, protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. Dozens of protesters were reportedly detained, even bystanders. Several of them were later sentenced to several days of administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized in part by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]

On 6 July, dozens of protesters gathered in the largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Astana (Nursultan), protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. Several dozens of protesters were reportedly detained, even bystanders. Several of them, mostly activists, were later sentenced to several days of the administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]

On 6 July, dozens protesters gathered in largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Uralsk, protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. Dozens of protesters were reportedly detained. Several of them, mostly activists were later sentenced to several days of administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized in part by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]

On 6 July, dozens protesters gathered in largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Almaty, protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. Dozens of protesters were reportedly detained. Several of them, mostly activists were later sentenced to several days of administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized in part by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]

On 6 July, dozens protesters gathered in largest cities of Kazakhstan, including Karaganda, protesting against the newly elected President Toqaev. Dozens of protesters were reportedly detained. Several of them, mostly activists were later sentenced to several days of administrative arrest. The protests were co-organized in part by the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan. [size=dozens]
On 6 July, a rally was organized by the ruling party Nur-Otan in Almaty, against alleged attempts to destabilize the country. The exact number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2019, around a dozen of female protesters gathered in Shymkent, near the building of local administration, demanding better social services, especially housing, for large families and families with disabled children. [size=around a dozen]

On 5 July 2019, the movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized simultaneous rallies called 'Seruen' (walking rally) in Almaty, Shymkent, Aktau, Aktobe and Taraz. The organizers aim to emphasize importance of civil freedoms. In Shymkent, seven protesters were detained. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2019, the movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized simultaneous rallies called 'Seruen' (walking rally) in Almaty, Shymkent, Aktau, Aktobe and Taraz. The organizers aim to emphasize importance of civil freedoms. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2019, the movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized simultaneous rallies called 'Seruen' (walking rally) in Almaty, Shymkent, Aktau, Aktobe and Taraz. The organizers aim to emphasize importance of civil freedoms. In Aktobe the protesters were approached and interviewed by police and told that the rally was illegal. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2019, the movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized simultaneous rallies called 'Seruen' (walking rally) in Almaty, Shymkent, Aktau, Aktobe and Taraz. The organizers aim to emphasize importance of civil freedoms. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2019, the movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized simultaneous rallies called 'Seruen' (walking rally) in Almaty, Shymkent, Aktau, Aktobe and Taraz. The organizers aim to emphasize importance of civil freedoms. The number of participants was not revealed. [size=no report]

On 5 July, over a dozen of civilians were preventively detained in Astana (Nursultan, 7 individuals) and Almaty (9 individuals), as they were suspected of organizing or calling for a rally for the upcoming day. Furthermore, law enforcers organized raids at homes of alleged members of the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan party and seized various electronic devices, mostly mobile phones.

On 5 July, over a dozen of civilians were preventively detained in Astana (Nursultan, 7 individuals) and Almaty (9 individuals), as they were suspected of organizing or calling for a rally of the DVK for the upcoming day. Furthermore, law enforcers organized raids at homes of alleged members of the Democratic Choice of Kazakhstan party and seized various electronic devices, mostly mobile phones.

On 4 July 2019, about 6 home mortgage holders gathered outside the office of National Bank of Kazakhstan in Nur-Sultan city demanding debt relief on their mortgages after the Kazakh government nationalized their primary lender Astana Bank due to bankruptcy. The issue was also related to the unfavourable exchange rate of the national currency Tenge against USD. [size=about 6]

On 3 July, a resident of Osakarovka district, Karagandy region was reportedly beaten and lynched by locals and later handed over to police. There he was sentenced to 15 days of administrative arrest (the crime was not reported), but not provided medical assistance; and although later transferred to a hospital, died. [size=no report]

On 3 July 2019, about 15 residents of Sadyr village in Panfilovskiy district of Almaty region protested against lack of access to the grazing land around the village due to restrictions imposed by the local farmers. Protesters demanded the district authorities intervene and resolve the issue. [size=about 15]
On 3 July 2019, more than 100 construction workers protested at the Abu-Dabi plaza in Nur-Sultan city demanding better pay and improved working conditions. [size=more than 100]

On 2 July, employees of a local cleaning company in Zhanaozen started a strike and gathered for a protest, complaining that their wages are not being paid on time. Reportedly, dozens of workers gathered. [size=dozens]

On 2 July 2019, about 15 female protesters demonstrated outside the Kazakh government's main building in Nur-Sultan city demanding child subsidies of 21000 Tenge and housing for the families with disabled children. [size=about 15]

On 2 July 2019, 10-15 homeowners protested near their properties in Turkistan city demanding the city authorities compensate them in a full and timely fashion for their homes after the city administration announced the buyout of the residential real estate in the neighbourhood for development purposes. [size=10-15]

On 2 July 2019, 15-20 residents of Lesnaya Polyana neighbourhood in the town of Koschi outside Nur-Sultan city protested against the local maintenance service provider accusing the company of forging signatures on their behalf and demanding the authorities get involved in their dispute. [size=15-20]

On 1 July, a video emerged on social networks of Kazakhstan, showing an attempt of looting of a group of around two dozens of locals, damaging a fence of a warehouse of the Khorgos international center for border cooperation (ICBC) in Almaty and trying to get inside. They did not succeeded, as law enforcers were protecting the building. Later, three men were arrested and two women fined. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2019, 20-30 protesters including Baitak-Bolashak environmental group activists demonstrated in Nur-Sultan (Tselinogradskiy, Aqmola, Kazakhstan) against the construction of a nuclear power plant and the land lease to foreigners. The protestors also demanding the release of political prisoners and more social support for the single mothers and socially vulnerable households in the country. [size=20-30]

On 30 June, a rally was held in the center of Almaty, co-organized by the Baita-Bolashak ecological alliance. Protesters opposed the proposed construction of a nuclear power plant, sale of agricultural land, corruption related to the environmental agenda and several other political topics. Around 200 of protesters gathered. [size=around 200]

On 29 June, clashes occurred among workers at Tengiz oil and gas field, Atyrau region. Reportedly, mass brawl took place among local and foreign workers, allegedly over unequal working conditions. Hundreds allegedly participated; dozens were injured. Later, foreign workers, especially Jordanian and Lebanese nationals, were transferred to another spot. [size=hundreds]

On 29 June, an employer of a private security agency beat a civilian in Pavlodar region [coded to Pavlodar], who tried to reach his cottage, but the guardian forbade him to enter the area (no reason for the refusal revealed). The victim was hospitalized.

On 28 June 2019, about 15 workers and managers of the construction firm protested at the local labor department in Almaty city demanding their wages for building a ski ramp nine years before for the Asian winter games. [size=about 15]

On 27 June, hundreds of protesters, predominantly local people, gathered in Shymkent, blocking a local road. They demanded explanation from authorities regarding the recent blasts of ammunition. A series of massive blasts occurred at an ammunition warehouse on 24 June - three individuals were killed, dozens injured. [size=hundreds]

On 24 June 2019, about 20 residents of Zhana Zhambyl settlement near the village of Bayterek in Zhambyl district of Zhambyl region protested against bad roads, poor quality power supply and lack of social services demanding the local authorities provide status to the settlement and resolve the issues. [size=about 20]
On 24 June 2019, around 40 employees gathered at a construction site in Almaty. The protesters claimed that they had not received salaries for three months. [size=around 40]

On 24 June, about two dozen of individuals gathered in Almaty, supporting a jailed activist and demanding medical examination of his condition, since he suffered from various chronic diseases. After negotiation with authorities from the local department of penal system, the examination was promised to be provided soon. [size=about two dozen]

On 21 June 2019, about 20 residents of the local neighborhood in Taraz township of Zhambyl region protested against lack of irrigation water supply on the block demanding the authorities provide access to the water source. [size=about 20]

On 21 June 2019, a group of citizens, predominantly women gathered at the Akimat of Shubarsu in Ordabasy and protested the actions of social services. They claimed that social services lose their documents to prevent them from getting social allowances. [size=no report]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Aktau. They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Taldykorgan. They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Almaty. They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. Reportedly around 30 individuals participated. [size=around 30]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Aktobe. They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Shymkent. They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 21 June, members of the newly-established movement Oyan Kazakhstan organized a 'walking rally' in several cities of Kazakhstan, including Nur-Sultan (Astana). They wanted to emphasize importance of the freedom of speech and peaceful assembly, which is, according to them, in serious danger in the country. The exact number of participants was not reported. [size=no report]

On 20 June 2019, 20-30 residents of Balgabek Kydyrbekuly village in Zhambyl district of Almaty region protested against lack of natural gas supply in the vicinity demanding the local administration complete the state financed gas supply infrastructure project which would resolve the issue. Protesters accused the authorities of embezzlement and corruption after finding the local farm was connected to the gas supply line separately from the village. [size=20-30]

On 20 June 2019, about 10 female protesters demonstrated outside the Almaty regional administration's office in Taldykorgan township against unfair distribution of the state subsidized housing among listed applicants demanding the authorities investigate irregularities. [size=about 10]

On 19 June 2019, about 20 cab drivers of the Astana Taxi service company protested outside the city administration's office in Nur-Sultan city against the company's plan to raise fees for the drivers from ten percent to twenty percent demanding the authorities intervene to settle the dispute. [size=about 20]
